fields.body: [{"type": "button", "value": {"text": "How to get sponsorship for your developer event", "page_link": null, "external_link": "https://developer-portal.prod.mdn.mozit.cloud/communities/developer-events-sponsorship-guidelines/"}, "id": "42ca61a5-8f16-46e5-ac1f-ef138e839b52"}, {"type": "button", "value": {"text": "People", "page_link": null, "external_link": "https://developer-portal.prod.mdn.mozit.cloud/communities/people/"}, "id": "6786ddec-af0e-427d-beaa-c58d68c9b4d2"}, {"type": "button", "value": {"text": "Mozilla Tech Speakers", "page_link": null, "external_link": "https://developer-portal.prod.mdn.mozit.cloud/communities/mozilla-tech-speakers/"}, "id": "1eed4b04-91a6-479c-b5f6-6c0df61a8cb2"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Mozilla Tech Speakers are talented, trained technical speakers who present at conferences, organize workshops and trainings, and mentor others on technologies driving the open web.

The global Mozilla Tech Speaker program is designed to recognize, promote and develop the talents of volunteer technical advocates and educators who are interested in informing others about the open web and Mozilla products and technologies at events around the world.

Tech Speakers receive support from Mozilla in the form of speaking opportunities, public speaking training, briefings and technical training, and funding for their activities.

Are you looking for Mozilla to sponsor your event? The Tech Speaker Program is not what you are looking for, but we have a sponsorship program where you can apply for a grant.

", "id": "1a19ad6d-65ac-4fa0-80aa-52bb72bc27ec"}, {"type": "button", "value": {"text": "Become a speaker", "page_link": null, "external_link": "https://goo.gl/forms/WArLqjmwaHw9WQY43"}, "id": "ce62cef7-0e4a-4a0a-8940-29f68762237f"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Our goal is to create a strong community-driven technical speaker development program, with a global posse of talented tech speakers working together to advance the open web, with help from Mozilla.

", "id": "2e1e6d6d-5144-4464-9af6-9095cdb60fd1"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

We provide

  • Public speaking training
    We offer a comprehensive curriculum that includes professional coaching and peer evaluation.
  • Briefings and workshops
    We organize technical briefings and workshops conducted by industry experts.
  • Funding
    We support speaker participation in regional and global events.
  • Speaking opportunities
    We connect Tech Speakers with conference organizers looking for Mozilla speakers and assist our speakers in their proposal submissions.
  • Support from like-minded individuals
    We foster a community of individuals interested in technologies and public speaking. As a cohort, tech speakers assist each other and share tips and info.
", "id": "bff17e43-aaaa-465b-9fe3-2f2cb837b1c7"}, {"type": "embed", "value": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5wvDrxn-xVU", "id": "79b4acd2-f7db-4446-a2a2-750f103fa7bd"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Becoming a Mozilla Tech Speaker

Most of our Tech Speakers already serve in their communities as technical evangelists and educators before they join the program. Many, but not all, also contribute to Mozilla. All support the open web.

There are two ways to join Mozilla Tech Speakers:

Open application

Apply via our open-application process, which is held annually. Follow @MozillaTechSpeakers on Twitter or the Speaking category on Discourse for the latest information on timing for the application process.

Applications for the next cohort are currently closed, but you can register your interest and we will contact you when we will start a new cohort..

Nomination

Be nominated as a Tech Speaker by an active participant in the program in good standing or by an industry expert at Mozilla. This process is ad hoc and requires the completion of an evaluation process, including videos of past talks and an assessment interview with an internal expert. People who join the program this way are generally already being invited to large regional or global conferences and wish to affiliate themselves with Mozilla.

", "id": "b776d28b-974c-4640-8475-be8de8d9b5e9"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This page is for people seeking speakers or sponsorship for developer-oriented events

", "id": "5cb40c4d-c198-4c1c-9b03-c221da84c709"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Mozilla Developer Relations community seeks to help developers use open Web technologies. One way that we do this is by supporting technical conferences and meetups that bring developers together and share knowledge about open Web technologies. By support, the Dev Rel group includes financial sponsorship, help with securing Mozilla speakers, and Mozilla branded promotional items at the event.

", "id": "d43e0197-585d-4a3f-acd3-91956d58547d"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Contents

  • Developer Event Request Guidelines
    • How are requests made?
    • What kind of support does Mozilla provide for events?
    • Who reviews my request?
  • Sponsorship Follow-up
    • How will my request be reviewed?
    • What to expect after your form is submitted
", "id": "a86a19a6-1dde-43e4-ab36-b01c0cecc70e"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

How are requests made?

External and internal requests are made using the Developer Events Request Form. Support is provided in the form of Mozilla speakers, panelists, workshops, sponsorship, booths/tables. We ask that all requests are submitted at least 8 weeks prior to your event's date, so we have sufficient time to review the request, confirm a speaker/schedule their travel plans, fulfill sponsorship tasks, etc. If you have a question about events that is not covered by the request form, please email devsponsorship (at) mozilla (dot) com

What kind of support does Mozilla provide for events?

The Mozilla Developer Events team reviews requests for speakers, branding/swag, booths, and/or sponsorship at developer focused events. For hackathons, we look to support and encourage these events by providing speakers and mentors in the region.

We usually do not consider requests that require significant sponsorship (in general, above $5,000 USD). In cases where we do sponsor at a higher amount, there must be significant alignment with Mozilla goals and a strong partnership between the organizing group and Mozilla. Larger sponsorships generally encompasses a series of events or a high-profile opportunity and require contracts between the event and Mozilla.

Mozilla Reps or Community Members organizing Mozilla-oriented events must go through the Mozilla Rep in their geographic area. The Developer Events team coordinates with the Reps programs to make sure that events are not cross-submitted or funded from both programs.

If you are a Mozilla Community member organizing an event, please review the How To Guideline .

If you are seeking a Mozilla Tech Speaker to present at your event, please take a moment to fill out the Tech Speaker Request Form. This form gathers some basic information about your event and your specific needs, so that we can best match you with an appropriate speaker.

Who reviews and approves requests?

Requests are reviewed weekly (unless holidays and scheduling conflicts arise) by the Developer Events Team. The core team who evaluates requests is Sandra Persing and Havi Hoffman. Ali Spivak (Director, Developer Relations) participates in the call and makes the final decision to approve or not. Members of technical and engineering teams, such as Mixed Reality, Firefox Developer Tools, WASM, and others are both invited to the meetings and consulted before/after about suitability of specific events for their audiences/technologies, the appropriateness of requested topics, and for help identifying speakers (both within their organizations and volunteers/external people).

", "id": "e7599c78-39ff-47b4-8916-e42fe092859f"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

How will my request be reviewed?

We have established this set of criteria by which we evaluate all event support requests:

  • Alignment to Mozilla goals and strategy: Your request shows a clear relationship between the event and achieving Mozilla, Emerging Technologies team, and our DevRel|Developer Relations goals. We have a set amount of funding every year, and we need to make sure that our dollars are spent on events that are supporting the goals we have set for the year.
  • Brand Alignment: We will carefully evaluate the impact of having the Mozilla name and logo associated with the event submitted, and the people organizing/speaking/attending to make sure the request and our support is in alignment.
  • Diversity & Inclusion: Does the event demonstrate best practices in regards to speaker and attendee diversity?
  • Submission at least 8 weeks prior to event date: It takes time to review the requests. Please be considerate and respectful regarding this time frame to allow sufficient time for consideration.
  • Mozilla participation: Money alone doesn't represent Mozilla very well, so we consider first to sponsor events where members of the Mozilla community (volunteers or staff) are participating. They could be attending, speaking, organizing, or participating in some other way, as long as they are at the event in person. Note: If you have no Mozillians involved in your event, we are happy to help find someone to speak, attend, sit on a panel, etc., but this does NOT guarantee a sponsorship. Finding Mozilla participants is judged independently of sponsorship opportunities. We also look at historical involvement and feedback: Did the event meet or surpass expectations and best of class guidelines? Do we know and trust the organizers? Have there been problems with/at the event in the past? If there were, how did organizers deal with them? These will help guide a decision and influence the amount we choose to invest.
  • No pay-to-speak: We don't pay for sponsored speaking slots, or accept speaking slots that are contingent on sponsorship. We prefer that Mozilla speakers be invited or accepted on the quality of their presentations and the interest the attendees have in what they have to say, not because Mozilla has paid to put someone in front of an audience. We believe this policy:
    • is equitable to conference organizers seeking Mozilla speakers
    • is fair to other speakers who don't have the means to pay for a speaking opportunity
    • helps us gauge interest in the topics and products we might propose to speak about
    • maintains the credibility of Mozilla speakers with audiences
  • Budget consideration: This sponsorship request process is specifically from the Dev Rel team. We are limited in resources and usually do not consider supporting requests that require significant sponsorship (in general, above $5,000 USD). However, we are happy to review the event and its purpose to help direct the request to another Mozilla division.
  • Code of conduct: In keeping with Mozilla's culture of inclusiveness, we require event organizers seeking sponsorship or speaker to create, publish, and enforce a code of conduct for their event participants. You can find examples and guidance for writing a code of conduct on the Geek feminism wiki. Our Mozillians are awesome, and they all deserve to be treated with respect.
", "id": "9ab2239d-031a-4f4a-92a5-d598eba03540"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

What to expect after your form is submitted

Here's the general timeline (subject to change and exceptions): We review requests that are three months out from current date (for example, if it's currently January 2016, we are generally reviewing requests Feb, Mar, April of 2016. The DevRel Events team meets on a weekly basis to review requests submitted through the events bugs form. Email requests will be redirected to the form, and all communications will be followed up on the form. Sometimes, the team takes additional time to re-direct the request to the appropriate team, or to wait for replies that are dependent to the request submitted.

If Mozilla sponsors your event, please be aware that we will ask you for follow-up information after the event, such as number of attendees and social media reach. The purpose of this follow-up is to help us track the effectiveness of our sponsorships and make decisions for the future. You're probably collecting this information anyway.

For direct follow up and any questions, please email devsponsorship (at) mozilla (dot) com

", "id": "0df493c4-44eb-427d-81e6-3013922e9d52"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This site, developer.mozilla.com

brings together all that Mozilla has to offer developers, including what we\u2019re working on in today\u2019s Firefox browser, tomorrow\u2019s emerging technologies, and the content, products, and services that we build explicitly for web designers and developers. This is where you can discover tech events that are organized or supported by Mozilla, find out how to get involved with the programs we offer, and learn more about participating in the communities we support. Here, you can connect with Mozilla Developer advocates and tech speakers, interact with some of Mozilla\u2019s in-house experts, and find video and presentations from around the world about your favorite topics and technologies. It\u2019s also a home for resources and documentation specific to Mozilla and Firefox projects and products.

MDN Web Docs at developer.mozilla.org

is a comprehensive public resource providing education and reference material about web technologies. An ongoing documentation project staffed by Mozilla and supported by our partners and contributors around the world, MDN will always be maintained as an open public resource by and for developers.

", "id": "f05f6af2-474a-4b67-b34d-a0582d33036e"}]
fields.sidebar:
[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Want to get involved?

You can apply to be a tech speaker,

learn more about the process and requirements for obtaining support for your developer event,

and find out about being a technical contributor to our projects, such as AV1, Browser Extensions,

Mixed Reality, Developer Tools, GeckoView (our mobile web rendering engine), DeepSpeech or CommonVoice, WebThings, Rust,WebAssembly and more.

", "id": "1a81c222-2e44-49ee-a6be-a113664fb9da"}]

fields.body:
[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "
Customizable & portable mixed reality collaboration spaces. Based on open standards, designed for effective moderation and privacy. Accessible from your browser.

", "id": "2f14d9a6-1094-4d66-a045-8e945eac9e05"}, {"type": "image", "value": 575, "id": "4f772e60-c8ff-4143-a320-e9c1c40a858c"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Why Hubs matters

", "id": "71f5cd13-c04e-49c2-aabd-f30ddcbaa6ea"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In 1993, the internet was a very different place than it is today.

A biology teacher (for example) could independently create and publish a website about photosynthesis, instantly accessible to anyone using the web.

That was possible because of the lack of gatekeepers, and the comparatively low barrier to entry posed by HTML, which helped the web become the world's living room, office, library, and more . . .

Lowering the barrier to participation in and development of VR and AR spaces will have a similar transformative effect.

You can be a part of this.

", "id": "b3c0be39-aaba-471e-8d30-d7424ad8298b"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

No headset required

", "id": "be0a1598-6185-4b71-a9e4-407c13398ad8"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

All you need to use Hubs is a browser.

Mozilla's VR industry engagement, involvement with the creation of open standards, and deep knowledge of browser engineering make it possible.

", "id": "489487ea-e153-47c3-ad44-09412bf38f5d"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Customizable, portable, based on open standards

", "id": "37c81adb-1f7d-42fe-845d-540f48fe97bf"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Although a wide variety of environments and default avatars are provided for those who just want to use it "as is", Hubs is designed for customization, from environments and avatars to clients and extensions.

The file format at the heart of it all . . .

All Hubs models and scenes are glTF files. This API-neutral and royalty-free format was designed for interoperability, small file sizes, and quick loading. It's supported by a large number of content creation tools, as well as a flourishing ecosystem of utilities.

Environments

Spoke is a web-based environment editor created by the Hubs team. All you need to work with it is a browser. Either use the provided models and sounds to create an environment, or upload your own. You can also optimize scenes' performance to ensure they provide a good experience for users.

Avatars

It's possible to create your own models to use as avatars, as well as reskin the default model with a web-based editor.

Extensions

The Hubs Discord bot is one example of an extension. There are many other possibilities, such as Twitter, Twitch, or calendar application plugins. We'll be sharing more information about APIs in the near future.

", "id": "5ca96c59-8e31-49a0-9f55-de243576f0d4"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Hubs Cloud

Organizations and teams can deploy the entire Hubs platform to their own AWS accounts. This gives them full control over its administration and content, allows them to accommodate larger numbers of users, and makes it possible to customize the client.

Learn more about Hubs Cloud
", "id": "b0f58dc0-a1a5-422e-a5a9-4cd9e0908252"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Designed for effective moderation, security, and privacy

", "id": "74d85879-75d1-450e-9946-113f9ba7e669"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Mozilla's years of experience creating online communities has informed the Hubs experience.

  • By default, rooms are private. You can provide access to others via a link\u2014either permanently, or for a limited time.
  • You have fine-grained control over how users can create and share content in a room you administer.
  • It's possible to have a sense of shared space without being visible on camera.
  • You don't need an account to create or enter a room.
  • There is a comprehensive and thoughtful privacy policy. You own your data.

", "id": "f60208fa-36cb-49be-b602-47a9822d1b09"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Accessibility

", "id": "a9d77dd2-1bb4-4b74-ae0c-4d53b0f8cfd3"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Work is already underway to integrate more inclusive design features in Hubs.

One possibility already being explored is scene descriptions. They could be created using a combination of author-supplied information and machine learning techniques, perhaps specified in new custom extensions to the glTF models that make up a scene. The text output could be delivered to users as they wish through the client or browser.

", "id": "8e0d173d-02ef-4c63-859b-8548a64680d2"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

A space for creation

", "id": "8e669964-a1e1-41bb-836e-a09a8d7360d9"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

A shared environment is especially important for groups doing activities like brainstorming and ideation, particularly as related to 3D content. In Hubs you can import objects and other content, draw socially, communicate via voice, and more.

", "id": "8bb657e1-7a9c-4669-a3ea-3bf2448b64a7"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Join the project

", "id": "0c5bea1b-c2b3-4d80-88da-67b80f71c7db"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Want to get involved more directly with the development of Hubs? We're welcoming contributors.

Working with a headset? Here's a list of those supported.

", "id": "12ad7c11-34ab-4e68-bbcc-c18fa0f3f6d9"}]

fields.body:
[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "
  • What is WebXR? A new web standard from the W3C for virtual and augmented reality on the open web.

  • What happened to WebVR? WebXR supersedes WebVR. WebVR was never a W3C standard. WebXR can do everything WebVR could do and more. All WebVR implementations are deprecated and will be removed in the future.

  • How do I move my WebVR content to WebXR? If you are using a 3d engine like ThreeJS you probably won\u2019t need to do anything. For more info see the WebVR Migration Guide

  • What browsers support WebXR? The Firefox, Oculus Browser, Chrome, Samsung Internet, and more have all committed to shipping WebXR in their current or future versions. See the MDN page for more info.

  • What devices support WebXR? Most VR headsets support WebXR through a compatible browser.

  • How do I build a page with WebXR? WebXR handles the immersive part, but you still need a way to draw 3D content. Generally this means using WebGL. Since WebGL is very low level most developers use a 3D engine or library like ThreeJS, Babylon or others. Your favorite 3D engine may support WebXR already.

  • How do I get viewers for my WebXR site? Let us know about it so we can feature it on the Firefox Reality homepage.
", "id": "b69b2b32-d140-4c81-a028-2ac66b25dd9a"}]

[{"type": "image", "value": 726, "id": "e8aba294-b220-433f-a6da-5cd342ac2379"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

At the MDN Swag Shop you can get dino t-shirts, bottles, aprons, and more. The proceeds support MDN's efforts to provide quality, continuously-updated learning and documentation resources to help you build the web.

", "id": "41cf384d-2544-4734-b349-c32affd7a69e"}, {"type": "button", "value": {"text": "Visit the shop (EU)", "page_link": null, "external_link": "https://shop.spreadshirt.co.uk/mdn-store-eu/"}, "id": "e1e22afd-9a26-4f0b-92d7-d928c897a753"}, {"type": "button", "value": {"text": "Visit the shop (US)", "page_link": null, "external_link": "https://shop.spreadshirt.com/mdn-store/"}, "id": "a88d6caa-5d18-44d0-ae78-68678aacf450"}, {"type": "button", "value": {"text": "Visit the shop (Australia)", "page_link": null, "external_link": "https://shop.spreadshirt.com.au/mdn-store/"}, "id": "e982d8c7-e8fe-4aa0-a56d-a06e854fbbb9"}]

fields.description:
On this page, you can access all of the videos from the Developer Roadshow 2019.

We are extremely pleased to include subtitles in languages spoken in countries visited in the Asia segment of the tour: Japanese, Korean, Chinese, Thai, and English. In addition, two talks were presented in Japanese, two in Chinese, and one in Singlish creole.

fields.card_description: A conference focused on JavaScript, CSS, performance culture, responsive design, image optimization, UX, performance budgets, frameworks, monitoring, browsers, mobile devices, and perceived performance.

fields.description: An event organized by members of the Python communities in Vancouver, Seattle, and Portland which brings together Python users and developers from both the Pacific Northwest and around the world. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

fields.card_description: An event organized by members of the Python communities in Vancouver, Seattle, and Portland which brings together Python users and developers from both the Pacific Northwest and around the world.

fields.description:
This conference will be held ONLINE.

Talks by internationally renowned performance developers with a focus on front-end web performance. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

Note: The event is now fully online, with more speakers and an online conference party.

fields.card_description: Talks by internationally renowned performance developers. Their focus is on front-end web performance.

fields.description: Rust Belt Rust was a two-day regional conference about the Rust programming language. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
Rust.Tokyo was a one-day conference for Rustaceans with 200+ attendees. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
Script was an independent one-day, curated and handcrafted JavaScript event for the community, happening in Linz, Austria. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

The #a11yTO Conference was focused on digital accessibility. Its target audience was developers with an intermediate to advanced knowledge of web development and accessibility, with a willingness to learn. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
Aleading event in the French web community, Paris Web has many gathered speakers and a highly-skilled, demanding audience since 2006. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
This was a hacking oriented event with an unconference format and focus on open source Web engines topics. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

This was a web developer conference focused on Javascript and related technology.

Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

BSides PDX 2019 was an open environment for the InfoSec community from Portland, the Pacific Northwest, and the rest of the US to engage in conversations, learn from each other and promote knowledge sharing and collaboration. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
Dev Day 4 Women was a technical event focused on bringing more diversity to the tech scene. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

This was a 2 day gathering organized by the LLVM Foundation and many volunteers within the community. Developers and users of LLVM, Clang, and related subprojects attended talks, impromptu discussions, and networked with the community. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

The RuhrJS is an annual, community-driven JavaScript conference and the first of its kind in the metropolitan Ruhr Area in Germany. In 2019 it brought together an international line-up of renowned speakers with 200 JavaScript developers from all over the globe, creating a forum for them to connect with companies and one another. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
CONNECT.TECH 2019 was the largest multi-framework front end annual conference in the USA. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
A single day, single track conference about the joy of computing focused on technical topics. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

VideoLAN Developer Days (VDD) 2019 was a developer focused event for engineers working in open-source multi-media, specifically around audio and video playback. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

At this event, authors and cultural management experts Christopher Liechty, Danny Damron, Ph.D., and Scott C. Hammond, Ph.D. educated technical localization professionals about how to meet their business objectives in a global, distributed tech team. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

Keeping up with rapid developments in technology, build tools, infrastructure, artificial intelligence and software ethics is a full-time job. The goal of this conference is that attendees come away with renewed inspiration, new friends, mentors and mentees, and a notebook full of notes to explore back home. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
Write the Docs brings everyone who writes the docs together in the same room: Programmers, Tech Writers, Support, Designers, Developer Advocates, and more. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
Armada JS was the first JavaScript conference happening in Serbia, covering a wide range of JavaScript-related topics. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
This was a volunteer-run conference focused on browsers, associated with the London Web Standards group. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

This Front-End Developer Conference is now in its 8th year. It consists of two full days with four tracks to choose from each day. In 2019, there were over 50 presentations, panels, live coding sessions, and round table discussions, plus opportunities to network and connect, including evening events each day. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
A one-day, single track, community-oriented conference focused on development best practices and problem solving. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
This conference offered talks by a mixture of local and global speakers for an international audience. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

JSConf Korea is a nonprofit conference that pushes the boundaries of what can be created using JavaScript, and provides opportunities for people with diverse experiences to share their thoughts and to exchange positive energy. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
This event is a member of the JSConf family. In 2019, it was a single track community conference. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
At this free event, the public and W3C members participated in an evening of demonstrations, presentations, and discussions with the W3C community. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

Strange Loop 2019 was a multi-disciplinary conference bringing together developers and thinkers building tomorrow's technology in fields such as emerging languages, alternative databases, concurrency, distributed systems, security, and web production. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

This was a single-track, two-day front-end web development conference. Day One covered "Layout, Organisation, and Optimisation" and Day Two covered "Aesthetics, Motion, and SVG" . Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

ARTIFACT was an intimate, 2-day, single-track conference for web developers and designers addressing new development techniques, performance, design systems, and designing for diversity and inclusivity. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
This French-language event focused on creating smooth and fast user experiences. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

HalfStack is a collection of four UI-centric JavaScript conferences focused on inspiring, informing and entertaining the community. This year the events were in in London, Vienna, Phoenix, and NYC. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
JSConf US 2019 was a two day, two track conference focused on providing a platform to develop unusual ideas into widely-known products, ideas, and libraries. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

Abstraction II was a multi-disciplinary conference bringing together designers, developers, DevOps specialists, managers, quality assurance, and community leaders — to teach, learn, and connect. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
This was a community-focused event with an informal but professional atmopshere. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

The fifth View Source conference provided attendees with guidance on best practices for building for the web, and insights into how browser vendors and others, create and support web standards. It was organized by Mozilla Developer Relations. Videos are now available.

fields.card_description: The fifth View Source conference was held in Amsterdam September 30-October 1 2019. It provided attendees with guidance on best practices for building for the web, and insights into how web standards are created and supported. Videos are now available!

fields.description: This was a single track two day programming conference with a focus on community and social responsibility. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
This was a one-day conference featuring talks and hands-on workshops on technical and non-technical topics. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
The Game Devs of Color Expo was an event that aimed to uplift people of color in video games and share knowledge about game development. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

DinosaurJS 2019 was a community-run conference in the JSConf family that has had a diversity ratio of 50% over the past three years. Diversity scholarships were also offered. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
Pixel Pioneers 2019 was an affordable one-track community conference for front-end developers and UX/UI/web designers. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

This event was a celebration of five years of Women Who Code Portland. It featured a panel of women who have excelled in their tech careers while also giving back by creating tech communities online and in their cities. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
This was an event focused on showcasing the voices of marginalized people and allies in tech by creating an inclusive environment. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
Multidisciplinary conference addressing design, technology, and ethics. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
Curated two-day one-track UI and CSS conference. Seventh edition. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
This is Southeast Asia's largest web developer conference. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

OSCAL is the only international annual conference in Albania organized to promote software freedom, open source software, free culture and open knowledge. This was the 6th edition of the conference and gathered more than 400 FLOSS users, community members and developers. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

JSConf EU is a professional, not-for-profit, labour-of-love conference for the JavaScript community. It’s a two day affair, with many related side events in the days surrounding it. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

This event included three days of packed sessions, social events and workshops, in wonderful Utrecht, NL. There were 22 speakers, speaking in 2 tracks, 400/500 developers, plus a live-stream to 10+ countries worldwide where side-events took place. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
CircleCityCon is a hacker conference in downtown Indianapolis. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
This event brings together programmers, tech writers, support, designers, developer advocates, and more each year. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

This was Knowbility’s annual web accessibility training conference. It included three-and-a-half days of keynote talks, workshops, and hands-on computer lab sessions in seven professional tracks: Development, Design, Usability/Testing, Content, Usability, Admin & Policy, and for the first time in 2019, a dedicated K-12/Higher Education track. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
This was an edition of the famous "Beyond Tellerand" series, in Dusseldorf. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
This is the largest annual gathering for the community using and developing the open-source Python programming language. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
This was a day of presentations about leading web tech topics. The event also provided hacking spaces and venues for group discussion. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

Techstars Startup Weekend brought experienced and aspiring entrepreneurs together to network, learn, and experience what it's like to create a startup. Day 1 focused on pitching ideas and building teams; Day 2 focused on learning from business mentors and working on the idea; on Day 3, teams pitched their idea to a panel of judges. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

This was a Rust Community conference in Asia with 1.5 days of talks and 2 days of workshops. Presentation proposals were reviewed via a blind CFP process. Organizers adopted RustFest/Rust Belt Rust processes. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
This was the 6th JSUnconf and took place in Hamburg, with 400 developers and consultants in attendance who use JavaScript, either privately or in their work. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

FITC Toronto is a globally recognized industry event showcasing the best the world has to offer in design, digital development, media and innovation in creative technologies. It included three days and nights of presentations, parties, installations, and performances. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

This was a single track, single-day conference about Embedded Systems and IoT development in Rust, with a training day on the day before and a hackfest on the days after. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

This SmashingConf hosted around 500 professional designers and developers from all over the world, with a balanced mix of male and female designers, front-end developers, UX experts, IA architects, marketing managers, and more. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

This was a technical conference focused on free and open source software. It included one day of community hacking, two days of dual track presentations and one day of training. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
This was a single track front end web performance conference with an introductory workshop and post conference MDN performance hackathon. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
This was an evening of live demos, special guests, product updates, and networking with the community. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
Presentations at this event were focused on front-end, UX, performance, accessibility, security, interface design, debugging and fancy CSS/JS techniques. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
Javascript developers from around the world, and Romania, met at this event. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

This event was part of the Global diversity CFP day where numerous workshops hosted around the globe were focused on encouraging and advising newbie speakers to put together their very first talk proposals. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
A single-track conference focused on front-end development. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
JS Kongress 2019 explored the role of JavaScript as an influence on modern software and cloud architectures. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

GirlScript Summer of Code was a 3 month long Open Source program conducted by GirlScript Foundation, with the aim to help beginners get started with Open Source Development and encourage diversity. Throughout the program, participants contributed to different projects under the guidance of experienced mentors. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

Now in its 12th year, FITC returned to Amsterdam to host their groundbreaking design and tech event on the future of innovation, design and everything in between. This is part of a series of events that continues until February 19th, 2020. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
This event took place at Dépôt 57, a new Virtual Reality Arcade in Brussels. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

FOSDEM is a free, community-organized event that takes place in Brussels every year during the first weekend of February, providing software developers a place to meet and be informed about the latest developments in free and open source software. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
This was the Warsaw location associated with the 2019 Global Game Jam. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

Devspace 2019 was a student organised developer conference providing a platform for organisations and industrial experts to interact with the students of VIT. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
This was a HTML5 game development gathering meetup for a local community. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

Mozilla Developer Roadshow is a meetup-style, Mozilla-focused event series for people who build the web. In 2019, we returned to Europe to tell the story of how the web continues to democratize opportunities for developers and digital creators. Mozilla was proud to collaborate with beyond tellerrand for the series of developer events in Germany and Austria.

Dan Callahan - WebAssembly in the Browser and Beyond

Nuremburg only

Philipp Bauknecht

Vienna only

Max B\u00f6ck (with HJ Chen)

The CSS Mindset: Fireside chat with HJ Chen and Max B\u00f6ck

fields.description: Mozilla Developer Roadshow is a meetup-style, Mozilla-focused event series for people who build the web. In fall 2019, we shared highlights of the latest and greatest Mozilla and Firefox technologies in Asia to tell the story of how the web continues to democratize opportunities for developers and digital creators. These events were organized by Mozilla Developer Relations.

fields.description: The Mozilla Developer Roadshow is a meetup-style, Mozilla-focused event series for people who build the web. In 2019, we participated in the Future of Everything Festival in New York (May 20-23) and also presented at Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles (April 23rd). These events were organized by Mozilla Developer Relations.

fields.description: This tour visited 10 cities: Chennai, Bengaluru, Manipal, Kolkata, Delhi, Pune, Ahmedabad, Nashik, Bhopal, Jaipur. In each city, a bootcamp of 2 days was conducted. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

An intensive 6 weeks training which culminated with a graduation ceremony, where some key players in the Nigerian tech ecosystem delivered tech related speeches and experiences in order to encourage the newly trained and other attendees at the event. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

This Hackathon took place at SUNY Plattsburgh over 24 hours. Presentations and workshops covered a wide variety of topics, including development and cybersecurity. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

The Journées du Logiciel Libres (JdLL) is a free annual event open to everyone curious or passionate about the free (libre) culture. It took place in Lyon over a weekend and gives access to various animations: talks, workshops, round tables, booths, DIY area with 3D printers (notably) and animations for children. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

3 day single track conference with workshops alongside talks, with 2 day sprints/hacks. Topics varied from to web development in general and topic relevant to the Django Framework. There was a high emphasis on diversity in talks, encouraging 50/50 female/male speakers. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

An event in the southeast of Sao Paulo state. This year was the fifth edition. Its mission is to provide a great event for developers from the small region of Jaboticabal, where they can learn about new technology. Presentations were about web development and content in many different languages (Python, PHP, Javascript, C#, Java, and more). Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

WebConf was a cycle of conferences oriented to web development, with speakers from all the country. Speakers exposed topics related to the development of modern web apps, such as PWA, NodeJs, Main FrontEnd Frameworks, good practices and new technologies. The conferences pushed the growth and participation of the local community. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

hack.commit.push is a Hackergarten all-day event where developers and project leads worked together on open-source projects to improve documentation, fix bugs, develop features. There were also "open-source 101" workshops at the beginning of the day for beginners. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

More than 400 of the world's top Rust developers came together for keynotes and talks by Core Team members and major contributors plus an optional day of top-notch training. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

This event, Hosted by GDG Ranchi, DevFest Ranchi covered multiple product areas such as Android, Google Assistant, Firebase / Identity, Google Cloud Platform, Flutter, Machine Learning with TensorFlow, and Web Technologies. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

SPLASH is the ACM SIGPLAN conference on Systems, Programming, Languages, and Applications: Software for Humanity. SPLASH embraces all aspects of software construction and delivery, to make it the premier conference on the applications of programming languages—at the intersection of programming languages and software engineering. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

Programming language agnostic conference that covered a wide range of topics such as: Functional Programming, Machine Learning, DevOps, Microservices, Multiplatform Development, Internet of Things, Cloud Computing, Information Security, Continuous Deployment and Integration, Tips for Juniors, Soft Skills, and more. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.
A small, community-driven conference in the heart of Vienna for designers, developers and makers of the web. Sponsored by Mozilla Developer Relations.

Mozilla Developer Relations is a travel sponsor for this event, supporting the participation of specific speakers and attendees.

Open Source Festival attracts student delegates, developers, designers, and corporate organizations with a series of talks and workshops to promote awareness of open-sourced developer tools.

A one-day, single-track conference about all things WebAssembly. Mozilla Developer Relations is a live caption sponsor for this community event organized by Mozilla and Google, to support inclusivity and accessibility.

This is the third edition of Global Diversity CFP Day, including numerous workshops encouraging and advising newbie speakers to put together their very first talk proposal and share their own individual perspectives on any subject of interest to people in tech. This event is organized by Mozilla Developer Relations.

A two-day, single track conference focused on building a community through a shared love and learning of JS. 22 talks of 25 minutes each along with food and breaks. Mozilla Developer Relations is a live caption sponsor for this event, to support inclusivity and accessibility.

SmashingConf is an inclusive, practical and friendly conference on front-end, design and UX, with CSS/JS techniques, accessibility, performance, privacy, internationalization, designing for mobile, HTML email and real-life case studies. Mozilla Developer Relations is a Platinum level sponsor of this event.

SmashingConf is an inclusive, practical and friendly conference on front-end, design and UX, with CSS/JS techniques, accessibility, performance, privacy, internationalization, designing for mobile, HTML email and real-life case studies. Mozilla Developer Relations is a Platinum level sponsor of this event.

fields.description: JSHeroes is a yearly single-track conference dedicated to JavaScript developers all over the world. Mozilla Developer Relations is a diversity sponsor for this event, to support participation by people in underrepresented and disadvantaged groups.

The focus of JS Kongress 2021 is Scaling JS – Pushing the Limits: Massive Platforms, Data-Driven Architectures, and Modern APIs. Mozilla Developer Relations is a diversity sponsor for this event, to support participation by people in underrepresented and disadvantaged groups.

beyond tellerrand is a single track festival for web developers and designers. The event is well-known for its very inclusive and familiar atmosphere. Mozilla Developer Relations is a Platinum level sponsor of this event.

beyond tellerrand is a single track festival for web developers and designers. The event is well-known for its very inclusive and familiar atmosphere. Mozilla Developer Relations is a Platinum level sponsor of this event.

This event is about growing and showcasing powerful voices of marginalized people and allies in tech in an inclusive environment. It includes a combination of workshops, keynote, and track sessions to expand knowledge, hone technical skills, and make important connections. Mozilla Developer Relations is an accessibility sponsor for this event, to support inclusivity.

Join Mozilla contributor for WebThings, Kathy Giori, at a workshop in which we will learn about IOT, learn how to assemble SnoPixel microcontrollers, and discuss the importance of STEM education for younger generations. Mozilla Developer Relations is a sponsor for this event.

The event page includes videoconferencing information.

fields.description: This event will feature sessions by seven world-class speakers about curious, badly-known, or otherwise interesting CSS features. Mozilla Developer Relations is a diversity sponsor for this event, to support participation by people in underrepresented and disadvantaged groups.

IndieWebCamp Austin 2020 is a gathering for independent web creators of all kinds, from graphic artists, to designers, UX engineers, coders, hackers, to share ideas, actively work on creating for their own personal websites, and build upon each others creations.

IndieWebCamp London 2020 is a gathering for independent web creators of all kinds, from graphic artists, to designers, UX engineers, coders, hackers, to share ideas, actively work on creating for their own personal websites, and build upon each others' creations.

CSSConf is a worldwide organization dedicated to holding conferences for designers, programmers and web interface creators, with the purpose of connecting the community in different countries. CSSConf Colombia joined the family in 2019.

Mozilla Developer Relations is a Silver level sponsor of this event.
HalfStack is a collection of fun, relaxed, single-day, single-track, UI-centric JavaScript and web conferences. Mozilla Developer Relations is sponsoring this event.
HalfStack is a collection of fun, relaxed, single-day, single-track, UI-centric JavaScript and web conferences. Mozilla Developer Relations is sponsoring this event.

Tech Interior was born as an alternative for students and professionals in the areas of IT, in order to bring news and the big names of the national technology scene. Mozilla Developer Relations is a Gold level sponsor of this event.

This event is being held online.

This singletrack event will be focused on things that use the web platform to express creativity, e.g. music, art, VR, thought computing, robots, games, poetry, comedy, etc. It will include 19 sessions covering a full range of time zones.

Tickets will be available in early April.

This workshop is intended to raise interdisciplinary discussions regarding technology, evaluation protocols, interaction techniques, applications, research ethics and legal regulations for social VR as an emerging immersive remote communication tool. Speakers include Mozilla's Blair MacIntyre.

RustConf gathers Rust developers from around the world to learn and share with one another. It kicks off with optional training courses which lead into the Day 2 schedule of keynote speeches, technical talks and a community happy hour.

The IEEE (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers) is an professional organization which offers a variety of resources including conferences. In 2020, the IEEE VR conference was held in Mozilla's Hubs mixed reality space.

fields.description: A one-day educational conference covering the processes and tools foundational to open source, open tech, and the open web. The target audience includes developers, technologists, students and decision makers. The format includes TED style keynote talks as well as track sessions from industry experts. Mozilla Developer Relations is a Bronze level sponsor of this event.

With a focus on engaging presentations, alongside spaces to connect, communicate and keep in touch with everything around the conference, you'll be immersed as if you were there. Mozilla Developer Relations is a diversity sponsor for this event, to support participation by people in underrepresented and disadvantaged groups.

fields.description: EnthusiastiCon is a conference for the programming community. We will talk about what excites us the most about programming — the strange, the wonderful, and the clever solutions to unusual problems. Mozilla Developer Relations is a sponsor of this event.

200 OK brings 200 web professionals together virtually for a day full of talks covering the full stack of modern web development. We emphasize open standard web topics in front-end, back-end, mobile, design, security, privacy, database, and devops technologies. Mozilla Developer Relations is a sponsor of this event.

We’ve also added localization settings so that you can choose your country, language, time zone and unit preferences.

fields.subtitle: All of Mozilla's developer resources – in one place

fields.description: A directory of Mozilla staff, Mozilla Tech Speakers, contributors, authors, and guests.

MDN content team manager Mozilla. Drummer at vulturiceye.com, loves noisy/crazy/weird music. and tinkering with web technologies.

I work on: Managing the MDN writer's team, MDN content strategy, and technical writing when I can find the time.

Particular areas of interest — beginner's learning articles and demos (Learning Area), web apps and APIs, WebAssembly, HTML/CSS/JavaScript, accessibility.

fields.job_title: Global Strategist, Developer Outreach: Sponsorship + Event Production
fields.description:
7+ years refining and redefining relationships with developers around the world. I create long term engagement programs for 18+ million developers and designers that scale.

I lead cross functional teams that create, organize, and produce events to promote frameworks, open source, VR XR, and voice web technologies. Three branded developer conferences produced under my leadership (such as View Source) are now annual tent-pole industry events.

Playful web writer/editor, communicator, event designer, marketing manager, content strategist and curator with 20+ years experience on the internets - from Yahoo Picks of the Week to Mozilla Hacks blog.

I’m a Designer and Developer Advocate at Mozilla and a member of the CSS Working Group. I'm especially interested in the coming revolution in GRAPHIC DESIGN ON THE WEB.

I SPEAK AT CONFERENCES and MAKE VIDEOS. From 2011–2015, I was the host and executive producer of THE WEB AHEAD.

Hi. I’m Dan Callahan, or callahad online.

I work in Developer Advocacy for Mozilla, where I help introduce developers to new tools and capabilities on the Web, as well as advocating for their needs within Mozilla.

When not attending and speaking at Tech Speaker events, Elio is a User Experience Designer and Researcher at Censored Planet of the University of Michigan where he helps with measuring internet censorship. He also founded Ura Design, a small design studio which focuses on improving usability and user adoption of open source software.

His focus lies in making internet freedom tools more usable and accessible. As part of this effort he has been involved at various projects in the past as well, such as Tor Project, OONI, EFF and Freedom of the Press Foundation.

As part of the Albanian open source community, Elio has co-organized OSCAL (Open Source Conference Albania) while serving on the board of Open Labs, a non-profit based in Albania.

I’ve been working in and around software engineering for 10+ years, and loving every minute of it.

What really drives me, however, is community. I’ve been actively working with children, refugees as well as software developers both new and experienced.

To me, a healthy community makes a healthy paradigm of software. Let me help you achieve that coveted AHA! moment.

Ankit Gadgil is an Open Source enthusiast who supports Privacy by design. He is an open web advocate who believes the web should be equally accessible to all for equal opportunity. He likes engineering software through comprehensive architecture and design.
Ankit is a Mozilla community mentor, Mozilla Reps Peer, and a Tech Speaker.

As a day job, he contributes code at Red Hat as a Senior software engineer and enjoys working with Python, Java, and JS.

He has been active as a community and developer evangelist for Mozilla and The Open Web mission. A contributor to the Mozilla Project since 2012, he has worked on a series of initiatives including:

* Firefox OS launch

* Teach the web

* Privacy and Security trainings

* Online MOOCs

* Mozilla Reps project & Web Literacy pathway

* Mozilla Reps

* Mozilla India Community management & more.

He has been contributing to the various Mozilla Projects as a Mozilla Reps Peer, for the Mozilla Reps governance body and a teach Speaker.
Contributor to Mozilla projects: Firefox Browser, FirefoxOS, Community Building, MOOCs, facilitating at events about "teach the web" movement teaching people how to create content for the open web. Help plan and pave the way forward for the Mozilla Reps project advancing the Mozilla mission forward.

Community Mentor with more than 7 years of experience in community building, outreach and mentoring, Ankit aims to help the open web continue to be the innovation platform it is.

https://reps.mozilla.org/u/ankitgadgil/

HTML5 Game Developer, Enclave Games indie studio founder, js13kGames competition creator, Gamedev.js Weekly newsletter publisher, Warsaw Open Device Lab host and Gamedev.js Meetups organizer.

JavaScript programmer, member of the Mozilla Tech Speaker initiative, active Hacks blog and MDN contributor, creator of a content kit on HTML5 Game Development for Beginners, active Firefox app developer, Captain Rogers creator, and frequent conference speaker.

Trishul is a professional Frontend developer; writes React code for living and volunteers for Mozilla to justify his existence. He promotes PWAs to developers #teamWeb. He loves to talk about modern Javascript and tries to use it to solve all of his problems, even the domestic ones. He is an expert in developing browser extensions.

He serves as Mozilla add-on reviewer and is a part of Mozilla representative group.

I work as a developer at Codevalue where I divide my time between teaching various web-related technologies and helping clients developing web applications. When I’m not busy organizing meetups/hackathons/speaking at events you can find me traveling the world and trying to improve my photography skills.

I have been a Mozilla Contributor for the past 5 years. Started contributing to Mozilla's Firefox OS Marketplace team as Senior Firefox OS app reviewer. Jumped to evangelize Firefox OS apps and Cross Browser extension development, I also contribute as Mozilla TechSpeaker where I visit college, tech meetups, conference to share my technical knowledge and my passion towards Rust programming language and Browser Extension development.
Web Developer, Open Source Evangelist, Privacy Teaching Task Force Member

Professor at FATEC Taquaritinga, Mozilla Tech Speaker since 2017, Mozilla Rep since 2018, member of Mozilla Reps Council, works with web development (front-end and back-end) since 2006, founder of Tech Interior (technology event in São Paulo state).

fields.job_title: Mozilla Fellow, Head of Advanced Development
fields.description: Leading exploratory engineering efforts in the Emerging Technologies organization. Also helping get new technologies more rapidly into Mozilla products, the open web platform, and the hands of developers and our communities worldwide.

Nathan Egge is a Senior Research Engineer at Mozilla and a member of the non-profit Xiph.Org Foundation. Nathan works on video compression research with the goal of producing best-in-class, royalty-free open standards for media on the Internet. He is a co-author of the AV1 video format from the Alliance for Open Media and contributed to the Daala project before that.

I am responsible for the care and feeding of contributors to Mozilla's add-ons community, including add-on developers, theme designers, AMO add-on reviewers, code contributors to AMO/Add-ons Manager/WebExtensions APIs, and end users.

I also work on add-ons communications & documentation.

fields.job_title: Senior Product Manager, Firefox Developer Tools
fields.description:
DevTools: Inspector, Style Editor, Responsive Design Mode, Accessibility, WebCompat

Platform: Layout

Guiding: Developer Experience, Developer Tools, Web Compat

Measure twice, cut once and keep crafting the web.

Guiding: Developer Experience, Developer Tools, Performance, Web Compat

#done Quantum, Performance Metrics, Benchmarks WADI/PWA, Firefox OS Apps Partner Engineering, Open Web Apps, Labs
Platform (Gecko and GeckoView) Product Management.

fields.job_title: Principal Research Scientist, Voice strategy and tactics, Mozilla Research Grants, and promoting science and design.
fields.description: I'm exploring new opportunities for Mozilla as part of Emerging Technologies. I run the Scout project, and I generally am involved with organizing Voice, Speech & Language Assistant work. I also run the Mozilla Research Grants and I handle the sponsorship for Research Conferences. I also help Mozillians with publishing their work in conferences, journals, and other scientific venues. I help people design experiments, surveys and studies.

Mozilla WebThings, Emerging Technologies -- strategizing, supporting, and evangelizing Mozilla's IoT effort. We are building a private, secure, and interoperable web of things implementation (Gateway, Framework, Libraries, etc.). Our open source software commercialization effort is focused on Smart Home uses. https://iot.mozilla.org, twitter: @MozillaIoT
AV1 is a royalty-free open codec for transmitting high-quality video over the internet, created by Mozilla and the Alliance for Open Media.

fields.description: CSS is a declarative stylesheet language used to describe the layout and presentation of HTML documents.

fields.description: Get the development tools you need to build mobile browsers and web applications. Mozilla uses GeckoView to power Firefox Reality, Firefox Focus, and other Android apps. GeckoView serves a similar purpose to Android's built-in WebView, but it has its own APIs and is not a drop in replacement.

fields.body: An overview of what we are working on at Mozilla - from new Firefox releases to WASM and much more! Ali Spivak is the Director of Developer Relations at Mozilla, and leads Mozilla’s developer documentation (MDN), content, events, and community participation initiatives.

We often think of DevTools for debugging purposes, but in recent years, Firefox DevTools have become more than that. The newer layout properties like Flexbox and Grid introduce behaviours that might seem confusing at first, but Firefox DevTools provides features that can help us better understand how the browser interprets the CSS values we assign. Hui Jing Chen is a self-taught designer and developer living in Singapore, with an inordinate love for CSS, as evidenced by her blog, that is mostly about CSS, and her tweets, which are largely about typography and the web.

Members of our Developer Roadshow Team share their thoughts on meeting with local developers in four cities in Germany and Austria. Featuring Diane Hosfelt, Hui Jing Chen, Dan Callahan, Fabien Benetou, and Marc Thiele.

An introduction to the emerging fields of virtual reality and augmented reality, where use cases often feel like sci-fi concepts brought to life. In this talk, Fabien Benetou explores the primitives that are the building blocks of every VR and AR experience and the Mozilla tools you can use to push the boundaries of reality in these exciting new technologies. Fabien Benetou is a WebXR developer consulting for the European Parliament, the UNICEF Innovation Fund and more.

WebAssembly began as an experiment in bringing other languages to the browser, marking a radical shift in the fundamental programming model of the Web. The project has just begun. Today, WebAssembly is poised to reshape everything from Node.js modules to containers, and even edge computing. But how is technology from the client side relevant to those domains? Packed with live demos and real-world examples, this session draws from WebAssembly's past to predict its future. Come find out where we'll be in 2020, and beyond! Dan Callahan is a Developer Advocate at Mozilla, where he works to ensure that the future of the Web is driven by the needs of real-world developers.

Mixed reality devices use always-on cameras and sensors to overlay virtual elements on the physical world. User privacy is an existential and essential question for this technology. This talk offers an overview of Mozilla’s approach to building an immersive web browser and a social VR platform that empowers users. Diane Hosfelt is the security lead for the Mixed Reality team at Mozilla and works closely with the Rust Project to improve security with formal methods and unsafe code guidelines.
Highlight a DOM node in the debugger.

Demo of the new WebXR emulator web add-on from the Mozilla Mixed Reality team.

* for Firefox https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/fire...

* for Chrome https://chrome.google.com/webstore/de... * GitHub https://github.com/MozillaReality/Web...

Read the post at: https://hacks.mozilla.org/2019/08/web...

Try the demos at: https://github.com/CraneStation/wasmt...

Debugging WebAssembly with LLDB

Read more at https://hacks.mozilla.org/2019/09/deb...

Just as WebAssembly is an assembly language for a conceptual machine, WebAssembly needs a system interface for a conceptual operating system, not any single operating system. This is WASI — a system interface for the WebAssembly platform. Read more at https://hacks.mozilla.org/2019/03/sta...

Kathy Giori, from Mozilla's Emerging Technology team, introduces Project Things and explains how you can get started with smart home security, monitoring, and automation. We're building Project Things with web standards to drive interoperability, and a decentralized framework to ensure privacy and security. We put safe home monitoring and automation back in your hands. Stay tuned for news about upcoming Project Things workshops.

Josh shares his WebVR boilerplate here: https://github.com/joshmarinacci/webx... Follow along with Josh, as he walks through what you'll need, and begins to codes up a virtual reality scene in ThreeJS to celebrate his niece's birthday. Learn how to use 'render' and 'initContent' in your scene...

Credits: Music - ayote&olympic hiphop hard by Annon via ccmixter.org (c) copyright 2016 Licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution (3.0) license. Artwork - John Howard, MonkeyInk.com Video Production - RyanIsHungry.com
Lin Clark and Till Schneidereit from Mozilla present at the first edition of the WebAssembly SF Meetup, January 24, 2019.

Josh selects a publicly available audio file that plays Happy Birthday, and codes in some other touches that bring the virtual reality birthday card scene to life. He finishes by uploading a new more realistic sky backdrop. Find the boilerplate here: https://github.com/joshmarinacci/webx...

Credits: Music - ayote&olympic hiphop hard by Annon via ccmixter.org (c) copyright 2016 Licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution (3.0) license.

Artwork - John Howard, MonkeyInk.com

How to add 3D text and text effects in virtual reality. Josh creates 3D geometry for the Happy Birthday text in his scene using Three.JS and open source true type fonts. Learn how to select your font, add a TTF loader, and chose your settings.

Navigation in VR is tricky. Josh explains how to code 'teleportation' targets in VR that let the user navigate to different VR locations in order to move around a virtual reality scene by jumping or 'teleporting' to a designated target. Find the boilerplate here: https://github.com/joshmarinacci/webx...

Credits: Music - ayote&olympic hiphop hard by Annon via ccmixter.org (c) copyright 2016 Licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution (3.0) license.

Artwork - John Howard, MonkeyInk.com

Video Production - RyanIsHungry.com

In this segment, Josh describes how to create realistic lighting for your WebVR scene. He shows how to adjust the background, and accurately apply standard lighting in virtual reality, including ambient light, directional light, point light, and spot light, as well as when to use these different types of lighting. Find the boilerplate here: https://github.com/joshmarinacci/webx...

Martin Fisch https://www.flickr.com/photos/marfis75/

In this tutorial, Josh shows you how to compose your virtual reality scene using the Spoke scene-building tool from Mozilla, and how to find a free 3D model from Sketchfab that you can customize and place in your own virtual reality scene. Find the boilerplate here: https://github.com/joshmarinacci/webx...

Josh shares his WebVR boilerplate here: https://github.com/joshmarinacci/webx... Follow along with Josh, as he walks through what you'll need, and begins to codes up a virtual reality scene in ThreeJS to celebrate his niece's birthday. Learn how to use 'render' and 'initContent' in your scene...

Developer Advocate Josh Marinacci describes the landscape of Mixed Reality today, and how to build and share a WebVR project in your browser with JavaScript and ThreeJS, and Mozilla virtual reality services Spoke and Hubs. Find the boilerplate here: https://github.com/joshmarinacci/webx... (

Background poster art by John Howard of MonkeyInk.com originally created for various releases of the Firefox JavaScript engine. )
