Horizontal text overflow has always been difficult to manage on the web. The default visible overflow is designed to make sure content remains accessible no matter the size of a containing box, but it's not our only option. We can now use overflow-wrap to control how words break – and combine that with hyphens to make wrapped text more readable. The solutions aren't perfect yet, but Miriam Suzanne will walk you through the options we have, and how to use them.

  • MDN Overflow-Wrap: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/d...
  • MDN Hyphens: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/d...
  • CodePen Demo: https://codepen.io/mirisuzanne/pen/GR...

Finally in 2019, we have new CSS that allows us a lot of powerful ways to style underlines. Jen Simmons walks you through the options. These three new properties on MDN:

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/d...
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/d...
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/d...

The CSS Specification for Text Decoration, Level 4:

  • https://drafts.csswg.org/css-text-dec...

When we're scrolling down a page, or through a gallery of images, snap-targets can help guide us from one section or image to the next. In the past, developers have used JavaScript to hijack scrolling, but now we can manage scroll alignment directly in CSS with only a few lines of code. The fallback even works well in old browsers! Miriam Suzanne shows you how.

Image Gallery Demo: https://codepen.io/mirisuzanne/pen/bX...

Page Sections Demo: https://codepen.io/mirisuzanne/pen/vo...

More on MDN: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/d...

The display property has been in CSS from the beginning, handling everything from block and inline boxes to list-items and full layout systems like flexbox or grid. Now the display syntax is getting an upgrade to match it's multiple uses. The new display spec adds flow and flow-root values, and allows for setting inner layout (grid, flex, etc) as well as outer box type (inline, block), and more. It might not be something we use much right away — but it still can help us understand all the power inside this one property. Miriam Suzanne explains the new syntax for Display.

Have ever set a width in CSS, and… nothing happens? It happened to me again, right after I filmed this video. There are a number of property & value combinations that can lead to CSS being inactive, and now Firefox will tell you why. Open the developer tools, and look for the greyed-out property with an info-box on hover.

It's a common pattern to align form labels and inputs in grid-like layout. I'll show you how to do it quickly using CSS subgrid, with several quick fallbacks. Subgrid will be available in Firefox 71, and you can use it already in Firefox Nightly – but there's no need to wait. Subgrid works great as a quick enhancement on top of you existing layouts!

Demo: https://codepen.io/mirisuzanne/pen/dy...

Card layouts are popular on the web, rows and columns of boxes with similar content. CSS grids can help align those cards, but it can still be hard to line-up content inside the cards: headers and footers that might need more or less room. That's why we need "subgrid" – coming in Firefox 71 and available now in Firefox Nightly. This is a great opportunity to quickly enhance our designs for modern browsers, without losing anything in the browsers without subgrid support. I'll show you how!

Demo: https://codepen.io/mirisuzanne/pen/xx...

For years, we've struggled to build resilient layouts on the web, but CSS Grid promises to change all that — and you can start using it now, with only a few properties and basic concepts. Learn how to build some previously-complex layouts in under 10 minutes, with only a few lines of code. Miriam Suzanne walks you through a practical demo.

Demo: https://codepen.io/mirisuzanne/pen/Jj...

Let's go deeper with the Firefox Font Editor. Jen Simmons shows you some of the nuances and details of the tools built into Firefox for refining your typography. For more: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/d...

Developer Tools have given us ways to adjust typography by editing our CSS in a browser for years, but can't we do better? Other graphic design programs have better tools for editing and adjusting our typography. Well, now, so do the Firefox Developer Tools. Jen Simmons will give you a tour of how to use the Firefox Font Editor to adjust typography on your site or others — including a dive into Variable Fonts: what they are and how to adjust them in a browser. For more: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/d...

We often want to set a CSS property "back to the default" — as if our stylesheets had never applied a style. `Initial` and `unset` seem like they could help us do this.... but they don't quite do what we want. The new `revert` value gives us a way to say "hey, go back to the browser's default styles for this property." Miriam Suzanne explains this new value and how it's different from what we had before.

  • MDN Docs: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/d...
  • Demo: https://codepen.io/mirisuzanne/pen/WV...
Have you ever wanted to grab a color from a webpage or an image? Firefox has a tool for that! https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/d...

Working on a website and need a quick way to send someone a screenshot of what you are doing? Firefox has a screenshot tool built right in the browser that you can use to quickly grab the entire web page, or just what's showing in the viewport, or hover over a specific element on the page and capture just that. For more:

  • https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/...
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/d...

Do you edit CSS in Developer Tools? Ever forget what you've done? Or tired of being limited by only being able to keep track of a few things? Well, Firefox Developer Tools will keep track of your changes to CSS and give you several options for exporting those changes to your CSS files. Jen shows you how.

fields.description: Did you know there is a way to see HTML in one pane, CSS in another pane, and a third Developer Tool at the same time in Firefox? Use that third pane to quickly access the Grid or Flexbox Inspectors, the Font Editor, the Animations Tools, Track Changes or more. There's also a quick way to preview how a page will print.

fields.body: Did you know there is a way to see HTML in one pane, CSS in another pane, and a third Developer Tool at the same time in Firefox? Use that third pane to quickly access the Grid or Flexbox Inspectors, the Font Editor, the Animations Tools, Track Changes or more. There's also a quick way to preview how a page will print.

When you create lists in HTML, browsers add bullet-points (for unordered lists) and numbers (for ordered lists). Now CSS gives us the tools to style those list "markers", and even create our own! - Use the ::marker pseudo element to style list bullets & numbers - Use display: list-item to add a counter on any element - Use counter-reset and counter-increment to create your own counters - Use counter() and counters() to control how counter numbers are displayed I'll also show you how the ::marker element is different from ::before or ::after.

Demo: https://codepen.io/mirisuzanne/pen/BaBKowO?editors=0100

When building a website, understanding what's happening with accessibility can help you make certain your site can be used by everyone. Firefox DevTools now has a new Accessibility Inspector that shows an outline of the accessibility tree, and lists problems with contrast or missing labels, and much more. Jen Simmons gives you a tour.

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/d...
  • https://hacks.mozilla.org/2019/10/aud...
  • https://hacks.mozilla.org/2019/06/how...

How can you easily check to make sure your choices of color are accessible — that as many people as possible will be able to see your content, no matter what kind of vision they have? Firefox Accessibly Tools can help you quickly test and know what decisions to make. Jen Simmons gives you a tour of the Color Contrast tools, and the Color Deficiency Simulator. Be sure to watch the part at 6:40 if the Color Deficiency Simulator is not showing up on your copy of Firefox. I'll explain how to get it. • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/d... • https://hacks.mozilla.org/2019/10/aud...

One of you left a comment on the video about Underline Styling — which resulted in us changing the implementation in Firefox, and likely other browsers as well. Jen Simmons explains how skip-ink and thickness interacted before the change, how the comment started a conversation at the CSS Working Group, and how skip-ink and thickness interact now.

Special thanks to bokkeman123 for their comment!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sZS-7...

Original Video on Underline Styling: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sZS-7... Demo: https://codepen.io/jensimmons/pen/xxx...

Issue Jen opened at CSSWG: https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/i...

Text Decoration 4 spec: https://drafts.csswg.org/css-text-dec...

There are many ways to start using a new feature in CSS without waiting for full cross-browser support, but "feature queries" are the most clear and explicit. We can use them to test for browser support, and provide targeted styles only where they are supported. Now we can do the same with new selectors, like ::marker or :focus-visible! Firefox 69 was the first to implement selector feature queries, but other browsers are following suit. Miriam Suzanne will show you how it works, and how to start using this new feature query right away.

- Firefox 69 Release Notes: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/d...

- MDN: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/d...

- Caniuse: https://caniuse.com/#feat=mdn-css_at-...

- Demos: https://mozdemos.netlify.com/support-...

Have you ever wanted to create more interesting shapes on the web, or flow text around the details of an image? CSS provides a number of built-in shapes we can use – from inset boxes to circles, ellipses, and polygons. Shape paths can be hard to code without a visual reference, but Firefox provides a shape editor to make it quick and clear. Miriam Suzanne will show you how to use the tool to inspect, edit, and create shapes directly in the browser.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/d...

http://www.widehive.com/artists

https://www.miriamsuzanne.com/2019/10...

https://codepen.io/stacy/full/449546e...

https://codepen.io/stacy/full/zjOeWa

https://adobe-webplatform.github.io/D...

https://bennettfeely.com/clippy/

https://labs.jensimmons.com/#shapes

https://codepen.io/stacy/full/aWKerN

fields.transcript:
Thank you, all, very much for still being here. It has been a long day. Your time is precious and I appreciate it. I appreciate you've stuck with it for the day. Also, thank you to someone who isn't in the room, Amanda, thank you very, very much for the live captioning that you've been doing. Thank you to Mozilla and White Coat Captioning for doing that.

A bit of housekeeping, just I'm contractually obligated by the Public Speakers Guild, as the last speaker of the day, to say I'm the only thing standing between you and going for a beer. I feel like, in this situation, because it's been two days of intense talks, I want to point out that you are the only thing standing between me and going for a beer.

So, I would like to talk to you, which is kind of weird, when you think about it. On two levels, I'm here to talk to you, like some clerical error on the part of Mozilla that's ended up with me here. I'm going to talk to you. I'm literally going to stand here on the stage, move my jawbone and pass air through my throat for, like, half an hour or so, right? And you're just going to sit there and take it. It's kind of a weird activity, what we're doing here, me talking.

But of course, the reason why it works is because I will be using language as I do it and hopefully we've all got the same codebase, English in this case. Language is amazing. I mean, language is one of the things that kind of makes us human. It was one of the great leap forwards in human civilization. Through language and moving my jaw and waggling this fleshy piece of meat, I can tell you something that happened and you are able to revisit the past. Or, I can imagine something in the future and relay that to you and you are able to travel to the future through language. So, language is a kind of time travel.

On a more basic level, it's a form of communication, which is also amazing. I can have an idea inside my brain and I move my jaw up and down, vibrate the air between us and transfer that idea from my brain into your brain. So then, language is like a virus. Right. It's almost involuntary. I can say, don't think of an elephant. You thought of an elephant, right? That's the auditory equivalent of the chicken game. You've played the chicken game and lost. That phrase "don't think of an elephant," that's from a book. He has written books on language and he wrote this one back in 1980, The Metaphors We Live By. This conceptual metaphor, which is what we're used to. You talk about one thing in terms of another thing and it's really useful when you're talking about something intangible. Time is a classic example. We can talk about time like it's a physical object. Time moving through space, time flies, time drags. Saving time, wasting time. Time is intangible, but talking about time with a metaphor like that helps us conceptualize it.

But what George was interested in was cognitive metaphors. Political language, in particular, the framing we use in language could maybe affect the way we approach thinking about things. He says, if you're going to have a debate about tax relief, you've framed taxation as something you need relief from. I think we are guilty of this, too. We talk all the time about what you can do now in the browser. The browser. Singular. Not browsers. Maybe this frames our thinking. So, I'm fascinated with the language and the metaphor we use to talk about the web and ourselves, the language and the metaphors to talk about ourselves.

The web's a relatively new medium. We tend to borrow from the medium that came before. This isn't new. This is something that Scott McCloud talked about. He is talking about how every medium borrows from the one before. He points out that many early movies were like film stage plays and television was taking radio and adding pictures it.

Now, this resonated with me because it reminded me of something I'd seen written somewhere else, it was something published in A List Apart. Who has read it? Good. Good. He makes the exact same point in this article, every medium borrows from the time before. Terrific article. By the way, I highly recommend you read it, even though it's 19 years old. It is more relevant now. John says this, when a new medium borrows from an existing one, some of what it borrows make sense, but much of the borrowing is thoughtless ritual. And over time, the new medium develops its own conventions, throwing off the existing conventions that don't make sense. So on the web, the medium that come before, if you were a designer, was print. It's not the web. Designers kind of wanted to recapture that control they were used to in print, on the web.

That's where we got Creating Killer Websites. This was 1996. Does anyone remember this? Awe, my fellow gray haired friends. This was the guy who came up with Tables for Layout and all the stuff Tejas was talking about earlier. This is kind of what John was pushing back on that maybe control shouldn't be what we're after on the web. Here's what John said: The web is a new medium, although it has emerged from the print medium. Yet, it is too often shaped by that from which it sprint. Killer Websites are those which tame the wildness of the web, constraining pages as if they were made of paper. Desktop publishing for the web. But he does acknowledge that, yes, we have a lot to learn from this history of not just print, but pre print, layout, illuminated manuscripts. This is the next leap forward, after language, is writing. Now we can communicate ideas and you don't even need to be in the same physical space, we don't have to vibrate the air between us anymore. I can make marks on wood and I can put an idea into your head. Kind of amazing.

So, with this kind of debate, I guess, between John talking about the flow and the flexibility of the web, the wildness and then David talking about constraining things into control on the other, they seem to be two very opposing viewpoints, and they are. We have a public document, PTC39 process. That outlines it. TC39 is unusual in that we operate on consensus. Not most of the room, in our case, it's the entire room agrees. In this case, consensus means something a little bit more subtle. It's that we don't have a specific block against a feature.

And we work through four stages. Starting with stage zero, the strawman proposal. Which could be any idea. Anyone can propose a proposal to the TC39. And it gets presented to the committee. We discuss if we want to do some more work in it which would lead us into a broader discussion about what this feature would mean and represent. That is stage one. From stage two we move on, from stage one, move to stage two where we are doing more detailed design work around the process. Once the design is agreed to by the committee, we move to stage three, implementation. And getting feedback from users based on the implementations. And finally, once we have at least two implementations and we have agreed and taken whatever feedback comes from this stage, we move on to stage four where it's considered part of the specification.

We have the web incubator community group and a whole range of topic specific community groups where people gather. Anyone can propose a community group, propose an idea. Start building it, start specing it out and bring it forward to a working group to put it on to the recommendation track.

And we as the W3C team and the community sort of evaluate, what's the interest? Do we have something that's likely to lead to multiple interoperable implementations? Which is one of the sort of necessary criteria for building to a W3C recommendation. Do we have enough interest from different parts of the community to make those implementations successful and useful? Go ahead. Then let’s put that on the req track and see what we can make of it.

>> So, I'm curious if we see, based on kind of this quick discussion of the different processes here, common challenges between groups on standards making here? Like obviously decision making is one. Do you guys want to address challenges here?

I think that's one of the reasons why I asked the question previously. Is developing standards on consensus the right way to do it? But it does make things very slow. And so, if you have people who are disagreeing, it can draw things out a lot. W3C, I have seen this happen. But it's in a little bit of a better place. And IETF, this is quite prevailing at the moment because it's been a large amount of work going forward to push security and encryption onto the Internet. And that's sometimes met, some companies have come in with some ideas which have kind of combated this a little bit. And so, there's sort of the decision makes around this gets dragged out a lot because of that. And work gets delayed because of that. That causes people to get frustrated.

So, it's a tough thing. I think both standards bodies do have some methods, something written in their process document for voting. So, if there really is no way that you can get a consensus, there is a voting fallback mechanism. But I've seen it used incredibly rarely in W3C. A little bit more in IETF with the methods we were mentioning earlier

>> And the W3C has taken on an initiative that you have worked on, the process for busy people and the process for 2020 document. What is it to revise process? That's the meta meta, right?

I write the process document for busy people. I'll link into it later. I did a tenure on the AB, I was on the group, it is a group that looks after the process document and some of the rung of the W3C. One of the things we do is look after the processing document. It's impossible to read. Even for someone with English as a first language, it was difficult. It was a simple document that bits got plunked on top of it. It became this monster.

We revised that to be easier to read and in simple English. I was proud, one of our colleagues who was Japanese translated it into Japanese. It was hard to do. This is not a legal document. It was a simplification of a legal document. I was proud about that. There is a great deal of work going on now with some very intelligent individuals to completely redo it and incorporate some very large pieces of work like evergreen standards. The name may have changed recently. Go ahead.

>> We face the tension between sort of agility and stability. Do we want standards that keep up with the tip of development in, you know, the most advanced implementation? Or do we want standards that you can refer to for a place that the platform is and will be for a period of time?

And, you know, different people want different set points there. So, we have been working on a process for continuous development, we're now calling it, to build in some of the reviews and some of the patent commitments. W3C has a royalty free patent policy that ensures that anyone can implement a W3C spec without faces patent royalty demand from anyone else participating in spec development.

So, we want to incorporate those things into a continuously evolving document rather than saying, it's only when it gets to recommendation at the end of the line that all of those assurances come in. And so, that is a fundamental change to the way the process has worked. And, you know, requires lots of different elements to work together. You know, we need to get the engineers and the lawyers talking together to make this process evolve effectively.

>> A nightmare scenario. Just kidding. We have been focusing a lot on these kind of formal groups. But I want to ask Aaron about process and decision making and community building in sort of those IndieWeb/open source spaces.

We do have a process as well for the specs that work through the IndieWeb community. It is much less strict. And there's no, like, timelines involved. I guess the idea is to get it to something that is, we don't ever consider a spec, like, final. We kind of treat everything as ever evolving because it's meant to document the reality of the world rather than trying to be like a declaration. But, you know, we mostly follow the microformats process. Which has been written up. It has changed over time as well. We have gone through iterations on that in terms of what exactly it entails.

But, you know, the process does have to be written down otherwise it is just gonna be chaos.

>> Yeah. For sure. And then, you know, we were talking about how this also slows that  a process can really be very slow moving. With the IndieWeb approach, it moves a little bit quicker. I think TC39 is interesting because of how we do the yearly standard. I wondered if you wanted to talk about that.

it is interesting. We have a rolling standard. We release the work we have done up to that point in the year as Ecma 2020. Everyone can make the joke, everything in hindsight is 2020. We do have a rolling spec. And the idea isn't that each year we come out with a new spec. It's really that we release the results of our work at that point. It's also interesting how this rolls into the staging process. Because at stage three, we're essentially sending it to implementers that it is now safe to implement because we will not be making significant design decisions at this point.

That's an interesting thing, going back to your point about stability and agility. We want to be able to change our minds and address problems that come up with specifications. But at the same time, we need to give a strong signal that it's safe to start implementing some very complex proposals. It's also a balance of those things. And, yeah, just to round that back to our rolling release schedule, it's sort of a point at which we make official that this is a recommendation from TC39.

>> So, learning all of these different processes, as we have been mentioning, is really, really difficult, right? W3C process document is a monster. It's really hard for newcomers to learn. I'm curious what different organizations are doing to sort of make process more knowable, make it more agile, make it more responsive to the way people want to work. Like the more IndieWeb way, I suppose.

So, I think one thing that's interesting coming from TC39 is our how we work initiative. Which was partially based off of the work that Natasha did with the how to  with the process document for busy people. Where we tried to write down our process and all of the culture around making standards at TC39 in a GitHub repository. That's available and accessible to everyone who wants to take part in that. And also, part of that was releasing a website that's geared towards developers rather than people who are already feeling comfortable working with spec language.

Because spec language is this weird space. Where it's semi legal, very abstracted language. For good reason, I think, also.

I think that's a big part of it - I don't even necessarily see that defining the process is the barrier here. Feeling you can be part of the process is the barrier. Because spec language is such an obtuse way of describing something. It's not the way you're going to learn the concepts behind what's going on and what's in the document. It is for good reason. It serves its purpose that way. But I think you need to have that other way of presenting the ideas more focused to people who are going to be writing the software and writing software using the technology. And I think that is a big challenge of like how do you make a lot of people know that is something they can participate in and actually get involved in the development of the standards.

There's a lot that standards bodies can still do in this area. I had some unbaked work, which is more sort of getting people up and running on W3C which I should revisit. One of the things that helped me as a new person within standards bodies was finding a mentor that was and it wasn't that I asked, will you be my mentor? There was just a few extremely helpful individuals that really started to help. So, if you are interested in getting involved, that was my number one thing. And actually, within W3C specifically, it was a Mozilla employee who became my mentor. Was co chair of my working group. Sorry, co chair of my interest group. And has been a long standing mentor for me within W3C. That's a big tip if you're getting started.

>> And I think the W3C has kind of started to experiment with buddy systems for TPAC and other systems.

Buddy systems and co-chairing. Chairing is a hard job and it's 365 days a year. So, don't ever chair by yourself. Don't do that. It's a tough gig.

>> Never chair.

So, a co chair really helps. And especially somebody who has a different skill set or different level of experience to you. And then eventually you will be that person who has that experience mentoring your co chair. That's what W3C is doing that now. IETF has been doing that for a long time. It's a good group.

>> Are there other resources y'all can think of? I think when We have been experimenting with, it's a little it's baking right now. Is outreach groups for TC39. I don't know if you want to mention that.

So, one thing that we've noticed in TC39, it's often hard to bring people in and get their feedback. So, we've started directly reaching out to specific groups. For example, we have an outreach group for educators, an outreach group for tools and frameworks. And we go to them. Because we can be a little bit intimidating to talk to. And the goal there is to make sure that we get a broad view on how people are understanding our proposals. What places are our blind spots, what we're not seeing. And these take the form of a monthly or bimonthly telecom calls. So, that's something that we have been trying out.

>> I think W3C, both, you know, takes in ideas from the community and so, some of the innovations that we've seen recently. Moving to GitHub was spurred by community members saying this is where we do work. And, you know, let's not use Mercurial or CVS checkouts anymore. But frame our issues through pull requests in GitHub. And that's moved to most of our working groups. We do almost all of our work in public available to anybody to watch and participate in the discussion. And then, you know, we need membership for the patent commitments at the time that you're trying to contribute to spec development.

So, we get from the community the idea of explainers and so, it's not just the process. But sometimes the technology in a spec itself can be difficult to parse from the spec. So, an explainer written in simpler language of, what are we trying to do here? What will success look like? What's required to make this API or feature effective? Goes into an explainer. And somebody else who sees that meeting a business use case can add even if they don't have the technical knowledge of what it would require to fix that. Getting a broad sense of the demand for a fix can help spur others in the community to think about what would it take to address that need from web developers, from app developers, web apps.

And so, another piece that's relatively stronger in W3C is the role of the team. We have a large team of technical experts team contacts who are there to help in making it a useful forum. And so, if at any point you're trying to get engaged with the W3C group and can't figure out, is this right? Feel free to reach out to the team contacts. We're there to help steer you in the right direction.

>> The W3C is this group that has quite a bit of staff and management and that sort of stuff. What about the other groups? Do you have management? Is there a parent org that helps with any of this?

The IndieWeb is complete opposite. It's just individuals working on stuff together. And we're not even officially an organization. We're just a community with a website. And it works.

>> Do you pay for the domain? I'm sorry. Somebody Patreon him some money.

>> Was that the “where does the money come” from question?

>> Jeremy Keith asked me to ask where does the money come from, but we can have a more nuanced conversation about the participation.

I can give info on IETF. It's a non membership organization. If you want to participate in Internet standards, you can just do that. It's a tough crowd, though. They're up on their tech. And I learned this the hard way. If you go with a half baked solution, you're gonna have a bad time. So, I'll tell you about my bad time later. It was rather emotional. Yes, it is a tough crowd. But there's no financial barrier to taking part. They have three meetings a year. The rest of it's done over email.

So, and their remote participation for the meetings was very strong. I felt they have done some very good work in making it very access to believe people if you're not able to travel. The money from IETF comes from a few different sources. With the three meetings they have a year, there is an attendee fee. I believe they get some money from the large Internet bodies as well. Exactly.

>> And ECMA

>> ECMA

>> You know as much as I do about this topic. Yeah. So, we are part of ECMA International. We're a technical committee of that standards body. And so, they do have an exec com which Jory is part of. There's a general assembly where they discuss all the standards bodies. But we have been given a lot of freedom to determine our process and how we work. And they've also helped us define our legal relationship with individuals who contribute things to the specification. Because this can be rather hairy. For example, in some cases in the US, you will have a company that says work that you produce on your free time is licensed to the company.

And as a result, we need to make sure that we're in a good legal position that we can say that if someone implements the TC39 recommendation, then they are legally allowed to do so. Then  and that's an important legal protection. Which is, I think, part of the reason that we have the membership structure that we do. So, our membership structure is tiered. We have ordinary members. I believe that there are associate members. There's another member who I think there's small business numbers and finally NGOs. And they have different tiers depending on what the funding requirements for ECMA that year are.

>> I think you raised an interesting point, which is the impact of IPR on our groups and on our processes. Wendy, as our legal counsel on the stage, do you want to kind of maybe advise a little bit on the importance of that?

Well, I have to give the standard lawyer's disclaimer that I'm not the room's legal counsel. But I think we see a variety of approaches to IP. The primary concern tends to be patents. Nobody wants to be writing a specification only to find out afterwards that somebody claims patents on it. And demands royalties from anyone who implements or uses the technology. So, different organizations have different requirements. Some have a disclosure requirement. If you have or are aware of patents, you need to disclose to the org and the org maintains a record of those disclosures so that would be implementers can review to determine their own risk level and comfort with negotiating with those patent holders.

Others have so called RAND, reasonable and non discriminatory license terms where the patent holder can charge royalties so long as it's the same royalty to everyone. and so long as it's reasonable. Which is something that would have to be determined in a court of law if the parties can't agree among themselves what a reasonable payment is. And on the way to royalty free, which is W3C policy. That's saying anyone who participates in the group commits that any of their so called essential claims will be available royalty free.

So, anything that is necessary to implementation of the spec is available royalty free. Things that are optional features or extra add ons can still be licensed which opens up a business model of, you know, you allow everyone to use the standard and you sell enhancements. And companies do that. And that's both a motivation to participate in the standards work, get the core standard deployed everywhere.

And then convince people that you who know the technology are best positioned to add enhancements on the edge end. If you want to pay for that performance upgrade or that additional feature, then there might be a royalty involved.

>> So, I think this tees up a question fairly well. Because, you know, that's certainly accurate for  what you just described as sort of the standard practice for standards in other industries, right? But we're on the web and we value the open web. So, the question is, what are things that our standards groups are doing to make the standards process more open? Like, how are we making it more accessible? How are we making open standards licenses? Things like that. You know, more modern and open compared to the standards of yesteryear.

I'll start. I think we work both the royalty free and the copyright licenses to permit anyone to download our specs. Many of our recent specifications at W3C use a forkable license that is not using copyright as a restriction on who can do other things with the license with the spec. So, if you think we're doing a bad job, you can take the work elsewhere and we need to convince people that this community is the best place to keep doing the work.

Because, you know, we don't have the legal cudgel to stop them from taking it elsewhere.

With regards to sort of document creation and emails. Emails in IETF and in W3C, they are open. You can read them. Sometimes it's difficult to get there. But they are available. And you can see document creation from the beginning. Some people will start to work on documents in editors drafts and their own GitHub repository. But once it reaches the IETF or the W3C, these documents are available to read whilst they're being worked on. That happens freely.

And it's so adverse to how things are done in the teleco space. In telecoms standards bodies, you need a login, you need to be a member. In some cases, you have to pay to read the standard when it is done. So, it’s different, this industry. And it's really great to see that movement.

I think that was actually one of the things that really pleased getting involved with the IETF and the OAuth working group. I found the mailing list, finding the people there, having the conversations and realized I was participating. That was it. I had already joined.

>> Oh, I'm sorry.

>> But, no, I think that works really well having all that happen so out in the open.

But to your point, that's something you have to go actively searching for or stumble into. And that's sort of a barrier in many ways for people getting involved. Another thing I've heard that prevents people from joining is sort of that reputation for these spaces being kind of hostile. And, you know, that's not great. What are some of the things that our groups are doing to make  to kind of to change that? To change that culture?

In the IndieWeb community, everything is out in the open. Everything is CC0 license and out in the open. And we have a code of conduct where you are expected to follow it if you are participating in this community. We hold people to that. It's a very core part of it. The goal is to create a space where people feel welcome to participate and join. And I hope it works.

>> Yes, speaking of the code of conduct. Since you sort of were a driving force for that at TC39. Can you talk a bit about ours?

Yeah. Sure. A lot of people don't know, but we did at two and a half years ago adopt a code of conduct for TC39, the delegates that attend the committee. That was very important because we were getting a lot of feedback and certainly a reputation that it was a fairly hostile place and we had some really stressful moments. I'm proud of how the committee has turned around in terms of being willing to take that step. Which is a hard thing to do when we're a consensus based group. So, we had to get 60 plus people to agree it that. Some of who had a problem with that, but that's fine. Now we're moving on. It's been a really nice change. I think slowly we've started to see more of the conversations kind of tempered down. People, you know, apologizing, thanking each other. Like that kind of thing. And kind of really resetting the tone for professional conduct. Which is great. Because that's what we need.

W3C has a code of ethics and professional conduct. And a group that is working on revisions to that to improve the welcome there. We also have had sort of recent introspection and work on diversity scholarships for our TPAC meeting to help people to attend and to recognize that our community is not as diverse as it could be. There are underrepresented voices. There are people for whom it's more difficult to get the travel funding together.

And so, thanks to Samsung for helping to spearhead that initiative we've had over the past two years. The diversity scholarship fund with member and individual support that's helped to bring I think this past year it was seven people to the TPAC meeting. And, you know, all of that is to recognize that, you know, standards are only as good as the inclusive community that helps to make them.

So, let me ask one final question which is, you know, what can the folks here do to get involved with your communities? What can, you know, if you were gonna leave them with one directive to come participate and get involved, what would you ask them or tell them to do?

So, it's also interesting to look at this from the perspective of one place. Okay. So, context. I ran a survey last year about  asking developers what their relationship with TC39 was and how they wanted to participate. And that actually shed a lot of light. Because from our perspective, it was everyone wanted to do a proposals, propose a change to the language, get a feature in. But from the survey, a lot of people were like, I want to help, but I'm not too sure how or where to start from. You can write tests. In TC39, check out our test 262 on TC39's GitHub page. And there are lots of really friendly people who will help you get started writing tests. Other people were saying they wanted to help with documentation. And people were also say, I would love to give feedback, but I don't know how. And we haven't fully addressed this yet. We're trying to get some documentation together. This is something that we're actively working on to help people know how to give feedback and things like this.

Two places to get engaged. Any of our review groups, if you're interested in security or privacy or accessibility or internationalization, we have reviews on all of those. And we're always looking for people to help in doing those so called horizontal reviews. And if you have technical proposals or places you think the web could do better, check out the strategy funnel where we collect ideas and proposals and see either vote something up that's already in there or add an idea to the mix.

I would say the easiest way to get involved in the IndieWeb community is join the chat channel. It's available on IRC, Slack, matrix and disorder. All are the same room, chat.IndieWeb.org. Come to a web camp and meet people in person. See what you're interested in and what specs you're willing to help develop or build things with. It's a very friendly community, welcoming. We have an IndieWeb camp this week in New York and in two weeks in Brighton. So, lots of opportunities to join.

I would say for the W3C, the WICG incubator group is an interesting one to join. To see what ideas are coming in from the community, you can join the mailing list and get the emails from that. The other thing is start talking or speaking at events. That's what I did. I started being a bit of a fan person for service worker. I kind of really locked on to that really early on. It was because of the explainer document that Wendy referenced earlier. I was to explain the documents and I started talking about that and the work that was happening there. Also, just reach out to somebody on Twitter or another social media platform. There are some people in standards that are desperate for people to help. Do that mental thing and reach out to them and say I want to work on this. They will be so happy.

And I want to share two quick references. The web compat work from Mike Taylor's group is a great place to check out how to get involved in spec bugs and things like that. The web we want is another great place that's collecting ideas for, you know, gaps in the platform.

Just one last thing about TC39, if you're interested and you just want a starting place that will give you lots of resources, TC39's website, TC39.es has a lot of things and you can take a look.

Thank you so much for your answers to questions. We're out of time.

fields.body:
Please note the following links for attribution from Tejas Kumar's slides:

http://www.schillmania.com/content/projects/even-more-rounded-corners/
2. The green box from slide 9: https://markheath.net/post/keep-inside-rounded-corners-css
3. The "clearfix" graphic: https://html.dasow.com/399
4. Information about variable fonts, I learned from: https://alligator.io/css/variable-fonts/
5. The Houdini dots demo: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kQAci8m0SpE&t=964s
fields.transcript:
Hello! Thanks. Good to hear you. I wanted to play a little game to get started and that is called Unlocking my Computer. But also, let's do this. I want some participation. Humor me. I say view, you say source!

Thank you. You're the greatest crowd. I can't see any of you but I love you very, very much.

My name is Tejas, that is pronounced like "contagious disease." I don't have anything. I won't give you anything except a good talk. I work at a company in Germany. We help our customers access their own data. Really, what I love about my job is the people I work with, like these are the people I go see every day and they are smart and funny and all kinds of wonderful. We're not even hiring right now.

But, we're not here to talk today, about me, we're here to talk about the CSS, the style sheets that cascade. We'll talk about CSS kind of how it was back in the day. We look at CSS then and we'll look at CSS, today, and we might  if there's time do some CSS that's coming up. We have quite a bit of content. CSS, back then, was marvelous. I started with CSS, when I was 8 years or 10 years old and it was very different. Something, like animating graphics was not easy, like, you'd usually have to have something like this. This is a JIF or GIF. They didn't support many things back in the day.

Moreover, to do things like this was really difficult and when you did it, you felt this, like, satisfaction. Whoa! I created something with rounded corners, a drop shadow. This, in my day wow, I sound old. Back in my day...back in my day, this was a tabular layout with three columns and the top left had a GIF. And the top right was a rounded corner. It was hacks upon hacks upon hacks. And in some cases, we did a background image of this fixed size box and we're very careful with padding to not overflow it because if we did, everything would be great.

Sometimes we'd get the rounded corners wrong.

And your box would kind of bleed out of your hack and I tell you these things because I want to just appreciate that all of these things and hacks that we once used to write are now two lines. Yeah, that is worthy. Moreover, I used to struggle with layouts. I don't struggle with layouts anymore. What is clear fix? Growing up, I struck clear both. What does that mean? And I think I didn't even figure this out when Flexbox became a thing. This is how we used to do side by side column in our layout. This hack or workaround has been reduced to more or less one line. Incredible.

So what I'm here to tell you today, I tell you these things to drive home the point that CSS is evolving and CSS is growing fast and is enabling all kinds of beautiful user experiences on the web. In fact, because CSS is evolving, today, we need to take about CSS on today's platform. It might evolve before we stop and appreciate it today. That's what I'd like to do with you. We'll talk, in detail, about three topics. First one is layout. We won't spend a lot of time here, because again, oh, my goodness. I learned so much. I didn't even know you could animate Grid. I'm going to play with it when I go to work.

Second is typography.

And, third, extensibility. We need to move a little bit fast, so let's get right into it.

Layout, I'm not going to spend a lot of time on layout. Wonderful talks before. I will go through the way we do Layout and answer one question that comes at me very often, like, even in my job today. Let's try and do this. So, I'd like to show you, we're going to write ,as Ruth said, I've been talking quite a bit, so I'm going to write in code for most of this. So, let's make a folder. Let's call it "talk." I'm going to go into it. Can you y'all see? Is that font size okay? Okay. Two of you are wonderful.

I'm going to make an HTML file. Let's get the font size up here and we'll write an HTML. I'll do a shortcut and a box and another box and we'll say this is box one and this is box two. I want to illustrate a use case that actually people on my team actually ask me about. We'll trade another CSS file that we'll reference right here. I think it's "link." Cool. Index.CSS. And, let's spin up an HTTP server. That, with no cache. And so what we have running here is literally nothing. I'm so proud of myself. This is the pinnacle of my career right here. Blank page. Technically, it's fast because there's no code.

Let's write some code, so let's give our boxes some color. Let's say "background, red." With 50, height 50. And let's see what they look like. They look like nothing. I think I may have written some, what is that? They're both red. I want to distinguish them. So box two has a background. So, Layout, positioning things is what people sometimes struggle with. I want them side by side and so I see this on the web today, where we'll try to do something like this. I don't fault you. That works. But there's some odd space between them. If we inspect this, there's no margin or anything splitting them up here.

What we see is that there's just space between them. That's okay. But what happens if the height of the second one is uneven? So, if I have these, right? And it goes to the bottom for some reason, I'll use vertical align on top and this follows. I'll use vertical alignment middle because really, I want it centered and it goes under the bottom. I don't know. This is not to ridicule the platform, this is something I've struggled with and other engineers have struggled with. There is the bottom, but not quite the bottom, but baseline is. This is something we collaborate on extensively on pull requests at my work.

There's Flexbox, 90+ percent of people have heard of and use Flexbox. It moves the responsibility of Layout to the parent, which is kind of where I'm going and I believe that's the way to do it. We will remove the rest of the inline block stuff. So the children don't know about their placement, the parent does. We want a gap between them. This doesn't work in Chrome, but it does in Firefox. It's coming.

Instead, let's talk briefly about how we space these children. Who owns the margin? Some would say, well, do margin right on both or one. And so do that. There, they're spaced. Is that the best solution? I'm not convinced. And I'm not convinced because in a situation, say on mobile where children would wrap and we'll simulate that.

This, which kind of looks okay, except you've lost your gap and there's some ghost margin going on here. This is accentuated if you apply a margin left to the second child and you have this odd space offset. Who should own the margin? And my answer, from experience, that seems the most correct to me, I may be wrong, correct me if I'm wrong, the answer of who owns the margin seems to be the parent. So, if we turn this flex into a grid, we can get rid of this simulation here and what we do is describe our grid template columns to be min content.

We have the same layout. What happens on mobile? I could query and specify a different CSS layout. And that's what it looks like. So, to answer the question for layout, who owns the margin? For me, the answer is the parent. The parent kind of lays things out and the children sit there and look absolutely pretty.

Next topic, typography. On the web, typography allows us to do incredible things. We create these experiences, on the web, that allow people to feel things. It's about expression. We do that with fonts. Unfortunately, however, fonts have come under fire, particularly the famous web fonts. Some of them can be quite heavy. You ship a lot of code. You ship 100 kilobytes of just fonts because you load character sets and glyphs that maybe you don't need. You can compress them. But there could be a way you could help this and this is kind of my goal to talk about this.

I want to show you a trick I learned from the documentation of Google Fonts. Let's go back here. Let's go to Google Fonts and what we'll see a beautiful set of fonts. Let's use big shoulders display. I like this name. I'd like big shoulders someday. There seems to be a bug here, I guess it works on a wider layout. Is it open? There we go. It was speed and performance. Users still want a faster and performant browser experience, not surprising. So, we should spend all of our time on this, right?

The second piece of feedback was privacy and trust. Users are saying they want privacy on the web. They want trust with their browser. But still speed and performance was the number one ask.

The third piece of feedback, it was advertisements, also not super surprising. Users are asking for less ads on the web. But when you look through the comments and read all of them, you see that users are specifically asking for ads that don't track them. They're saying things like, I want less creepy ads. Therefore, if you put together the privacy and feedback items with the users that are asking for ads that don't track them, it becomes the number one thing that user are asking for, to change about the web.

So users are telling us that they want privacy. They are saying, I want trust with the browser. And in their words, I think the number one response was users literally just saying more privacy. This really caused us to realign and focus on what users are telling us. So after learning that privacy is top of the mind, we went out and interviewed customers about how they manage their online privacy. So after listening to dozens of users, our team started to quickly brainstorm and figure out how to solve these problems technically. We quickly realized that we were doing things out of order. We had to stop and take a step back and create a set of privacy principles that our team can stand by. We are calling our privacy principles, our Hippocratic Oath. Doctors take a Hippocratic Oath to behold standards for their patients. So we developed a Hippocratic Oath that we, as developers, can behold for our users.

We have responsibility. I mean, all of us, in this room, have a responsibility, as creators of the web. And it took us time to develop exactly what our responsibility is. This is not a simple technical problem. There is no clear answer to privacy. And we need to be cognizant of the fact that online privacy affects developers, publishers and advertisers, as well as browsers and it also affects users and their experience that they have on the web.

The laws have not fully caught up to the degree of power that we have, as developers. We therefore need to self regulate and at the end of the day, we need to do what is right for our users around the world. We developed four principles that we, as a team, can truly standby and they are control, transparency, respect and protection. Control. We will put you in control of your data. And whether you want us to delete that data or use it to improve your experiences. Transparency, we'll inform you when, where and whom is collecting data. Respect. We will always respect you and your choice. And if you do not want us to collect any information. Protection. We will protect your personal information and prevent unauthorized access to it and never share it unless we inform you.

'll give a brief overview of trackers. For many languages like English or Dutch, the line breaks occur at word boundaries where spaces or punctuation are used to explicitly separate words. Browsers, by default, are not going to break words. If you look at the first box, the word content plus the full stop at the end is a single, unbreakable entity and that's the width of that first box. But it also means that now multiple modules can use these higher level types to communicate. Because a C string will be different from a Go string and a C# string. But now they have an abstract concept of a string and can use it to invoke each other's functions. Which I think is going to be interesting.

Of course, there is more future stuff, SIMD is working on. Threads are in Chrome, and soon in Firefox, I hope. There's Tail calls as a proposal. That means that we are entering the world where some browsers have support for features and others not yet. And for that reason, I wrote a small library called WASM feature detect that does what it says and tell you if a browser has a support for a certain feature or doesn't. If you're excited about this, or tickles your interest, try it out. Hit me up on Twitter. I would love to hear what your ideas are. And with that, thank you for your attention.

fields.body:
Ever since responsive web design started, we've had a problem with the way images load on the web. Now, Firefox is fixing the problem. Add width & height attributes to all your images, and see load jankiness disappear. Jen Simmons explains how. Try out the demos for yourself: Fixed-width layout: https://codepen.io/jensimmons/pen/jOO... Responsive layout: https://codepen.io/jensimmons/pen/mdd... #webperformance #imageloading #jensimmons

  • Caption author (Arabic)
    • Muhammad Fawwaz Orabi
  • Caption author (Polish)
    • Maciej Jaros
  • Caption author (German)
    • Fabian B.
  • Caption author (Hungarian)
    • zkriszti
  • Caption author (Chinese (Taiwan))
    • Chih-Ching Chang
  • Caption author (Portuguese)
    • Queven Ribeiro

So you know a bit about accessibility and want start keyboard testing, but not sure where to start? The Firefox Accessibility Inspector can help you easily identify keyboard accessibility issues on your site and provide information on how to fix accessibility flags raised. Youri Wims teaches you how to configure your browser and system to start keyboard testing in addition to showing you how to use the Firefox Accessibility Inspector to troubleshoot a keyboard accessibility issue. Disclaimer: The Keyboard Issue Checker in the Firefox Accessibility Inspector does not replace manual accessibility testing, but is encouraged to be used in conjunction with it.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/d...

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/d...

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/d...

fields.transcript:
Hi. I'm Kadir Topal. I started my career as a web developer in the late '90s. And for the last couple years, I have been the product manager for MDN. Yes, we have done this MDN web development needs assessment. So, this project that I'm about to talk to you about started late in 2017. That was shortly after CSS Grid was fixed. And CSS Grid was actually a massive success. In the Mozilla developers relations team, we asked ourselves, how can we have more of these wins? How can we support that so that we do this again and again?

And CSS Grid was a success. And it addressed user needs. It shipped in all the browsers at roughly the same time and it came with tooling. In the case of Firefox, it was the Grid Inspector. And that was seriously awesome. But that said, CSS Grid was years in the making. And layout had been an issue at least since the late '90s when we abused tables to implement our UI designs.

So, looking at this, we had a few questions. Why did it take until 2012 to address this problem and 2017 to ship it to developers? How was this coordinated so it would roughly at the same time in all of the major browsers? What were the road blocks for that and what were the critical elements to keep it moving? We took a step back to look at it from Mozilla's perspective, mostly.

After interviewing numerous people involved in the process, we identified three distinct phases. You have the research phase, the standardization implementation and the adoption phase. And now as you can probably tell, this is a very simplified process. It smooths over many things. And it looks like a pipeline when it's actually like a loop or a loop of loops that loop on themselves. I mean, you get the idea. But this was good enough for us to get started.

And most of us had a pretty good idea about the adoption side because that's where MDN is. And that's where MDN shines. And we had some idea about the standardization implementation aspect of this. But we wanted to know about the research phase. How do we learn about developer pain points? What they need and what we should prioritize for the platform. We interviewed more than ten people involved in the process at different stages of it, and it became clear that there was no formal research really. At Mozilla we have an amazing user research team when it comes to Firefox. But for developer research, that wasn't as much the case. It wasn't as established.

And this is important because at a place like Mozilla, we had limited resources. So, we can't go after everything. And there are serious opportunity costs that we pay when we decide to do something. Because it usually means we can't do something else. And that's along the whole process. So, it's standardization and implementation, but it's the same thing when it comes to adoption.

So, this is what we heard from people that we interviewed. About how things are prioritized. And one thing really stood out. Because almost every single person said the same thing here. We need to hear from developers. And it makes so much sense. Because none of us can be successful without that part. It's hard to prioritize the right things without knowing what developer pain points are. It's hard to find the right solution, it's hard to get people to adopt something if it doesn't solve their problem really or if it doesn't solve the problem in the right way. For all of those reasons, we proposed the developer needs assessment. So, what is that exactly?

It's a prioritized list of designer and developer needs. It's a single and simple tool for harsh prioritization that's representing diverse populations and a huge feature space. It's published on MDN. It's not owned by a single vendor, though. We initially proposed this under the umbrella of the MDN board, we have representation from the W3C and industry stakeholders. Because we think as a community, we need to have at least a common understanding of the facts when it comes to needs. Even if we draw different conclusions from them.

And again finally, it's reproduced annually. And this is important. As an industry, we need to know whether we are addressing developer pain points. And to understand whether we are prioritizing correctly. We need to track needs and pain points over time so we can see the impact of those efforts, essentially. And if you this well, we think the MDN developer needs assessment, or the MDN Web DNA for short, it can be a voice of designers and developers working on web. And asking about web developer and designer needs and frustrations is not trivial. Because the problem space is so vast. And the audience is so diverse.

So, let me tell you a little bit about the process we went through for that. We didn't just slap a survey on the website. And I apologize up front because I'm not a researcher. We worked with the very talented Alison McKee from pinpoint research to do the research design and to conduct this. So, I'll try to do my best to channel her here. In January of this year, we started the process by fielding a survey so the product advisory board members where we asked for data that they would use for decision making.

And then we had almost 20 in depth interviews with web developers and designers before putting together the initial version of the survey. And that is because we wanted the survey to be rooted in the voice of developers and designers. And we wanted to do that from the get-go. Had we run the survey without the interviews, the questions would have been based on the perception of browser vendors mostly. And by conducting the interviews, we made sure to derive the interview questions from the stories of designers about what is important to them in their work on the web. But also, what the frustrations are for them.

And to go from the interview findings to the survey, we followed pinpoints analysis process. Going from observations at the very bottom, what we saw and heard, essentially, to insights, what they mean, to critical themes on the highest level to look at why it matters.

And we are continuing that process to incorporate the survey findings that we learned from these pilot interviews. And in practice, that means we transcribed 16 hours of interviews. We then coded them. And we then bucket them to derive insights from the items in our survey. And that is a very hands on process.

Okay. So, wait. This is the coding. And this is bucket thing. So, this is a very hands on process where you actually print things out. So, based on these themes, we constructed the survey question around the frustration of web developers and designers. And we continued to work with our product advisory board on the overall survey with pilot interviews where we watched people take the survey at every iteration to make sure that the survey questions were as unambiguous as possible. And with the help from 30 stakeholders from various MDN advisory board members, telemetry we put together the survey. It was fielded on MDN and through the channels of the board members, W3C, Google, Microsoft, Samsung and Bocoup. And it wasn't just in English like this one.

We localized the survey in eight languages. It's Arabic, simplified Chinese, English, French, Brazilian Portuguese and Spanish. It was important to get the input not just from people who speak and understand English. I'm happy to announce that after fielding this survey for more than four weeks, more than 76,000 people took us up on it, and more than 28,000 took the time to complete the survey from 173 countries, actually.

And just for the complete responses alone, that's more than 10,000 hours of time that developers contributed to help us understand what their pain points and needs are. So, we really want to make sure we make use of that. We good use of that. And we believe that this makes the MDN web developer needs assessment the biggest web developer and designer focused survey ever conducted. And with that scale come benefits. We can segment the data by experience level, by developer role, country, satisfaction. And we still have very high confidence in the results we get from that because the segments are big enough. So, there are definitely benefits to getting this many responses.

So, after talking about the survey in the abstract for so long, I thought I would share a few questions aside from the core of the survey about things that developers find the most frustrating. And these are in particular order. How would you rate your overall satisfaction with the web as a platform and set of tools to even I believe you to build what you need or want? What are the things that you would like to be able to do on the web, but lack web platform features to do? And what are the biggest pain points for you when it comes to JavaScript development? And we asked the same questions for HTML and CSS and WebAssembly.

And since it's boring to just see the questions, let me share a little bit about the results. The first one is the list of top five items that caused the most frustration across countries, roles, experience and so on.

The first on the list is interoperability. Having to support specific browsers. Yes, we do have to follow up. We will do a follow up on this about what browsers and what causes the biggest frustrations there. That's number one.

The second one is documentation. But specifically, documentation for frameworks and libraries and tools. Not web standards. This is ranked much lower.

The third one, again, interoperability issue. But this time the fact that developers have to avoid using a feature because it's just not implemented in all the browsers that they need to support. And fourth is testing across browsers. And fifth is once again an interoperability issue. This one about making design look and feel the same across different browsers. And I don't know about you, but I see a seam in this.

So, in our final report, we'll go back to the 16 hours of interviews and add detail and color for these items. Especially when it comes to interoperability because people did tell us in those interviews very specifically what causes themselves issues there.

The second item I want to share is this. When a new web technology that's relevant to your needs becomes available, what are the main barriers to adoption? And usually when this question is asked, regardless of platform, the documentation and sample code is the answer. That is what most developers care about. And it's indeed listed here. But it's listed in second place. The number one issue is  the number one issue and barrier to adoption is actually broad interoperability across browsers.

And it's not all bad, though. So, we asked the question, what is the biggest pain point you have with HTML? The number one answer is nothing. At least for one third of the people we asked. So, people working on that are doing something right.

And finally, how would you rate your overall satisfaction with the web as a platform and set of tools to enable you to build what you need or want? And this is a full 76% are either satisfied or very satisfied. And that's something to be proud of really as people who work on the web to push the web forward here of all places. So, I hope you can keep that in mind when you hear complaints about web development experiences. But this is something to celebrate too.

And we shouldn't stop there. So, what I just showed was just a preview. So, this and much more than this we will put into the full report that we intend to publish by the end of this month. And as I said, we want this to be an annual thing. We don't want this to be just a one time effort. So, the next iteration will start in March 2020. We'll then field the survey hopefully in May and publish the results in September 2020. Hopefully around before View Source so we can talk about it again at the View Source next year.

At least that's the timeline that we intend to go with. Hopefully it will work out. And this is also where we need your help and input. This is the first iteration of the survey, it's far from perfect, but it is a start. Since you are the target audience for this, we want  we need your input for this. We want the next iteration to be much better. And we need you to tell us what are your target audiences? How useful is this for you? What level of granularity would you actually need to make decisions based on this? And the goal is to hear the voice of developers and designers working on the web and to have a single and simple tool for harsh prioritization representing diverse audiences. And a huge feature space. And I'm extremely excited that we've made the first step in that direction.

So, many thanks to everyone who has contributed to that and I'm looking forward to many more of these.

fields.description: The Mozilla Developer Roadshow is a meetup-style, Mozilla-focused event series for people who build the web. In 2019, we participated in the Future of Everything Festival in New York (May 20-23) and also presented at Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles (April 23rd).

Firefox Nightly, Developer Edition, and Beta can be very helpful for knowing what's coming for Firefox in the future, and participating in creating new web technology. Jen Simmons explains which is which, what are the differences, and where to find them.

Selecting the correct ARIA Role for elements can be difficult if you don’t understand how they are categorized. In this video, Youri Wims teaches you about the 6 ARIA Role categories and offers examples of the how they are utilized on the user interface and within the accessibility tree.

Not sure where that default 8px of margin on the body comes from? Here's how to find out! Every browser provides a User Agent (UA) Stylesheet to give HTML elements their natural shape, and make our sites more readable by default. When we start a project with a reset or normalization stylesheet, it's the UA styles that we are re-setting or normalizing.

It's been far too long since we've published a new video on Layout Land. We've been busy launching a new channel all about the web, with many more people creating videos about CSS, HTML, Accessibility, Developer Tools & more. Check it out at https://www.youtube.com/mozilladeveloper. And stay tuned for more from Layout Land in 2020.
Singapore-based developer advocate Hui Jing Chen opens her CSS Subgrid talk in Korean.

An overview of what we are working on at Mozilla - from new Firefox releases to WASM and much more! Ali Spivak is the Director of Developer Relations at Mozilla, and leads Mozilla’s developer documentation (MDN), content, events, and community participation initiatives.
(Presented in Japanese) Brian Birtles shares his pet peeves about web animation, and offers some technological solutions.
(Presented in Chinese; includes English subtitles) Max Liu, Mozilla Engineering Manager for Emerging Markets, describes Mozilla's activities in creating Firefox Lite.
Stan Leong describes Mozilla's activities in Emerging Markets.
(Presented in Singlish, a Singaporean English creole) Singapore-based developer advocate Hui Jing Chen introduces CSS Subgrid.
New Zealand based Research Engineering manager Phil Lamb describes Mozilla's Mixed Reality offering and the web platform that's underlying.
Head of Audience Insights at Mozilla, Venetia Tay describes the research her team has done to arrive at their user-centric perspective on privacy in the browser.
A presentation by Singapore-based Grab engineer Sriraghavan Subramanian describes optimization of single page apps using techniques from the backend.

Karl Dubost introduces webcompat.com and speaks about the challenges of browser compatibility. His Mozilla colleague Daisuke Akatsuka speaks about Firefox DevTools and a browser compatibility-checker tool that's under development.
Kathy Giori introduces Mozilla WebThings, which offers a private, secure, and interopable IoT solution that's not dependent on storage in the cloud.
(In English) Brian Birtles shares his pet peeves about web animation, and offers some technological solutions.
Singapore-based developer advocate Hui Jing Chen presents her CSS Subgrid talk in Chinese.
